reviewText: You play Maximilian Augustus Payne, a former cop that talks in metaphors that really don't make much sense. Maximilian enjoys long romantic walks to the pharmacy to get more painkillers to be addicted to, alternatively he can lick other people's painkillers to claim them as his own and establish his position as the alpha male. Max also has made a hobby of jumping through windows and slamming into walls, he discovered this passion when he jumped through a car window and caused a massive crash which left the bridge destroyed, 12 dead and 73 injured yay! Due to slamming his head into so many walls and his crippling addiction, Max hallucinates seeing words as people say them. If Augustus collects enough of the oddly placed golden weapon parts, he ascends to a higher existence and becomes Midas, and every weapon he touches turns to gold. Oh yeah Max can MANIPULATE TIME because he does so many drugs Buddha came down to him and bestowed upon him the power to control time.\n\nLesson learned, do drugs, manipulate time and become Midas

reviewText:
The first thing worth mentioning about Max Payne 3 is the amount of detail in the environments. I say this because so many have complained about the graphics in Max Payne 3. Yet every single location you play through looks so believable, no environment looks vacant of life or detail. Just as impressive is how varied these environments are. You will play through apartment buildings, a cemetery, a prison, and so on. Sure these kinds of environments are almost common place in most action games, but in Max Payne 3 they have a level of detail that is so impressive you can't help but appreciate them more.

Gameplay wise, Max Payne 3 does not stray too far from the first two games in the series. As you take out enemies your bullet time meter fills up, once you have the amount you need you can trigger it to slow down time. Enemies, bullets, grenades, and other hazards are easier to avoid in bullet time, not to mention how impressive the feature still looks. Shoot dodge also returns, letting you dodge in any direction (left, right, forward, or backwards) in slow motion. This time around you do not even need to have any bullet time in your bullet time meter to use shoot dodge (although some will be consumed if you do use shoot dodge while having bullet time left).

Max Payne 3 really is a great action game and a great game period. It is not perfect, but the good aspects without question outweigh the bad ones. Whether or not your a fan of the first two installments in the series, Max Payne 3 is definitely worth playing.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Max Payne 3
Original Release: 2012
Genre Tags: Third-Person Shooter; Atmospheric; Story-Rich; Cinematic; Noir; Adult
My Overall Grade: A+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 15-30 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: Auxiliary
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Fans of the intellectual property; Aesthetes; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs
REVIEWMax Payne 3 is an outstanding action-shooter that offers a strong narrative and a highly cinematic experience.  If you are someone who wants raw action, and doesn’t want to see a lot of cutscenes or kill-cams: then you may not enjoy this. However, if you are someone who enjoys games that play like movies, this is something you must play.  In my opinion, Max Payne 3 is one of the best cinematographic-action games ever made and likely will be for a long time.

The first aspect I will highlight in defense of my opinion is the writing and dialogue. Max Payne 3 easily has some of the best writing I have ever encountered in a video game.  The overall narrative is interesting and entertaining, but the real beauty of the writing shines through in the dialogue.  There are several lines throughout the game that will evoke that inner-thought of: “that was a good one.”  And the excellent voice acting ices the cake to ensure the cutscenes have an A-one quality that rivals Hollywood movies.

Besides the main cutscenes that give life to the actual narrative, there are also many other cinematic features woven deep into the gameplay mechanics.  You can activate Bullet Time® and Shootdodge™ as you play through the fight scenes in each level; doing so will slow time and allow you to perform elaborate kill sequences.   Further, bullet-cams and kill-cams will pop up periodically to show some nasty kills.  There are also level-specific “special” kills that will slow time and create cinematic opportunities.

The fight scenes encompass the vast majority of the actual gameplay of Max Payne 3.  The game is very linear and generally ushers you from one shootout to the next, with a cutscene in between to show more plot development.  There are some secret areas and collectibles, but generally the areas where you are in control are rather small and undeviating.  However, this is perfectly aligned with the movielike feel of the game; and the levels are well-designed and diverse, so they never feel boring or plain.

The whole experience is brought together nicely by solid graphics and animations, a high level of attention to detail, and advanced physics and particle effects.

Now, Max Payne 3 is the third installment in the franchise.  It is technically a direct sequel, although it feels a bit more like a spiritual successor.  You can easily enjoy this game without having played the first two.  (Of course, it is still best to learn what happened in the story during the previous games).  Also the first two installments in the Max Payne franchise were created by different people than this one.  This game does go in a bit of a different direction compared to the earlier installments.  For example, it isn’t quite as dark and noir; and also eases a bit on the deep, psychological inner-war concept.  These, and other differences, upset some fans of the franchise (as seems to be a common theme in new installments of long-standing franchises). So be aware of this. I personally feel that all three games can be appreciated for what they are.

Arcade-mode, timed-mode, higher difficulties, and achievements all contribute to the possibility of many gameplay hours.  There is also a multiplayer mode that is pretty fun.  During the time I played, there was a decent amount of people who played regularly; although there were times I couldn’t find a game.  I actually liked the multiplayer a lot and played it for dozens of hours, but I will admit that most people will probably find it lackluster.

In summary, I highly recommend Max Payne 3 to anyone who would enjoy a heavily cinematic action-shooter and who would appreciate the amazing writing.  It is one of the best “plays-like-a-movie” games ever made.  Having said that, I can understand some of you just want action.  If you want pure gameplay and/or generally skip cutscenes in games, you definitely should look elsewhere for your next shooter.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
--------------------------------------BUYER BEWARE-----------------------------------------
Just a heads up for those who haven't bought this, and may think of buying it.
First you have to create an account on Social Club in order to activate the game and then it HAS to be permanently linked to your Steam account. Then if you want to change your privacy settings to private for instance on the Social Club account you have to Link it permanently to Facebook or Twitter account, before it will ever let you access the Social Club account.

This should be stated on the game store page IMO. For those of you who don't mind having everything public and all these accounts linked then it's not an issue. However I like privacy and don't have a social media account. The loss of privacy now adays just to play a game is ridiculous! Again there should be a notice to gamers considering the purchase about these things! If I had known I would NOT have bought the game.

This to me is nothing more than a sleezy data collection scheme.  AND YOU are paying them so they can USE you and your accounts for free promotion of their game at the expense of your privacy.

Which boils down to....Let me know these hidden requirements before I buy something because I don't want to buy something if these are things I'm forced to agree to. I'm old school, pay money for license and play game! I do not want to pay money in order to be forced into this social media crap!

EDIT (since some people were missing this in comments)
When I first registered this game and discovered the hidden account stuff, I sent a searing email to customer support at Rockstar Games about the account linking with Facebook and Twitter in order to change privacy settings. I also included this review to make them aware of what I posted publicly about their game policy. I gave them the choice of giving my money back, or changing my privacy. Whether it forced a policy change, it has since let me change my privacy settings without linking to a social media account.

*These additional account creation in order to play, and things like linking to social media ALL need to be optional.  Optional so that people like me can opt out of them completely, and those who like them can take part in them.

reviewText:
Before the release, there has been a lot of controversy regarding the new setting of the game. While the predecessors have been placed in New Noir York City, a large part of Max Payne 3 is set in São Paulo, Brazil. Indeed, the grim, dark streets filled with Russian mobsters and Valkyr junkies are no longer here, instead they have been replaced with nightclubs, favelas and luxurious cruise ships. After the events of Max Payne 2, our antihero returns to his home in New Jersey, where he lives the life of self-pity. That is until he meets Raul Passos, a former colleague from the police academy, who is doing a private security job for the Branco family. Max and his friend engage themselves in a conflict with the mob, and soon Max is forced to move out to Brazil as well. As you might suspect, things don’t work out well for him. Seriously, has things ever worked out for him?

The old comic-panel storytelling device is gone, but the flashy cutscenes definitely make up for it. Their visual aspect, heavily inspired by IO Interactive’s Kane & Lynch 2: Dog Days, actually plays a large role in storytelling as well. It represents Max’s constant hangover and tipsiness, with cut-up, multi-framed, noisy scenes, flashing lights and weird camera angles reminding me on my own drunken ventures and the morning afters, but let’s not get into that. Overall, Max’s story is an engrossing, brilliant experience, and what’s even more important, it keeps in touch with the noir aspect of Max Payne 1 and 2.

Max Payne 3’s gameplay is the old-school fun you remember from the previous games. There is a massive arsenal of weapons to choose from, ranging from revolvers, through micro SMGs and ending with a sniper rifle and a grenade launcher. However, you can only wield two one-handed weapons and one two-handed weapon at a time. If you choose to dual-wield, you drop the larger weapon. The cool thing about it is, all weapons are shown on Max’s body throughout cutscenes as well, and the way he reloads his pistol while holding a shotgun in another hand at the same time is one of the finest animations in gaming to date.

Here comes the first complaint though, after each cutscene, and there are a LOT of them, Max defaults to his one-handed weapon, which might sound like a minor thing, but is actually quite annoying and breaks the immersion slightly. It is something that should definitely be fixed in a future patch. The old gameplay mechanics are still here- both bullet time and shootdodge make a return, and you absolutely need to use them if you want to stay alive. You might think that the game has been dumbed down because of the newly introduced cover system, but you couldn’t be further from the truth. Not only does the health not regenerate even on the lowest difficulty setting (painkillers make a return as well, so you can’t make Max suck a thumb for a few seconds to recover), but the cover is also fully destructible. And so are the enemies.

Max Payne 3 is mercilessly brutal. The developers take pride in that it seems, since there is a button that allows you to slow down time to see your bullets shot at the last enemy in the area. And then allows you to shoot him some more. With 50 bullets more. To the chest. By the time the guy is down, his body has more lead in it than blood, and each of the wounds gushes blood and leaves bloodstains on clothes as well. The game utilizes the Euphoria physics engine known from GTA IV, and although some hilarious glitches might occur, you can feel the impact of the bullet with every shot, and seeing an enemy stumbling over a set of stairs never gets old. The game is a majestic theatre, a wet dream of John Woo and Chow Yun-fat, and a glorious sight to any gamer. The environments intensify the firefights even more- from shattered glass, through empty shells bashing the floor with every shot, to massive splinters falling off of wooden surfaces; the game is a truly thrilling ride throughout all 14 chapters, lasting about 9-12 hours.

reviewText:
Pros:

+Strong story driven title
+Narrative gameplay and cutscenes
+Gory
+Great Graphics
+Music fits nicely
+Voice acting is done great and fits in perfectly for the mood he’s portraying
+Cover system and slow time function are great
+Combat is good
+Very dark in nature
+AI don’t mess around


The Middle:

+/-Linear gameplay (this is up to the player who’s playing the game) – I felt they did an excellent job with the concept. It kept the player sucked into the story and at times made me forget I was going from point A to point B, but to go achieve that goal that was needed during that chapter. Not once did I think to myself that this was linear.
+/- Can sound emotional and/or depressing at times, but then again, this is where knowing the knowledge about the last two titles are crucial (I thought it fit in perfectly, but attitude reflects everyone differently when playing a game)



Cons:

-Can be a slow start or even a confusing start if you haven’t played the original 2 games (or didn’t even read about their story via some online source)
-Controls can be wonky at times or at times don’t feel fluid as it should be
-Multiplayer is dead


Summary:

You are placed in Brazil to protect some VIPs and the action takes off immediately. The story at first can start off rather slowly, but it does pick up rather quickly after the first two or so chapters. Max Payne is always narrating the story (as if you were reading a comic book or something similar), whether it’s telling himself to go this direction or a witty comment on why he took the painkillers. Some of the cutscenes do elaborate some portion of his past, but they don’t explain everything on what happened in his past. The cutscenes are nicely done and also give a lot of information for the chapter and the buildup to the final plot that shows at the end of the game.

The graphics are done excellently. A lot of detail went into this game. There is gore (for those who are squeamish), but it’s done right to fit the nature for this game. The blood splatter seems consistent to the bullet wounds and/or explosions, but not overly used when compared to other shoot-them-up titles (i.e. 5 gallons of blood on the floor with only one dead body).

The music fits nicely with the game and it doesn’t sound overwhelming or try take the focus away when listening to the cutscenes and/or when Max Payne beings a narrative discussion. The sounds are done right and the explosions/gunfire is not overwhelming when firing them off. Voice acting was done very nicely. It wasn’t bland, but it was dark and emotional; all relating to his past experiences.

The combat system is done nicely with the game. You’re in 3rd person view unless you pick up selected weapons that have a scope on them. The cover system is done appropriately depending where and how you stay in cover. If someone that has a height advantage above you, they’ll more likely hit you while you’re in cover, but the same can be done to them. The aiming is flawless. I had no issues aiming at their heads whether it was normal pace or slow-motion, though at times the controls do feel wonky. I would have moments where I would want to slow-motion in a direction and the controls would hesitate or be unresponsive. This would also be the case when trying to go into cover, but it would hesitate, I’d click again and it would send me into cover and then right back out of cover.

The AI hit their marks a lot more than most shoot-them-up shooters. This is why the cover system and slow-motion function are key. This isn’t a Battlefield or Call of Duty similarity. This game relies heavily on those two functions or the outcome will be your undoing. I really enjoyed this title and I haven’t played the other two titles. I did some reading on the story prior of playing this title, so I had some clue on what to expect when it came to his emotions and the reason why he was doing the things he did.

The game is rich in story, yet dark in nature. I was never bored or felt the gameplay was linear in any way, shape, or form. I felt the game was more of a movie that you control the main protagonist. I thought they did an excellent job at this game. I didn't play multiplayer because I didn't find any matches, so I cannot give a review based on any multiplayer aspects. Other than that, I would definitely recommend this game.

reviewText:
Being a Max Payne old school fan, I gotta say regardless of the major environment change I really enjoyed the new Max Payne layout and scenery.  There was plenty of varied locations to expolore through several chapters.  This game is lush with extreme graphical detail and surprisingly runs very smooth even on decent system nearly maxed out.  I just loved the Brazil outside areas - check my screenshots as to why.  Max himself is way different, albeit his attitude is the same - someber and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off but his look is drastically different.  Now hes sportin a bald look and beard with hawain shirts and wife beaters.

The audio was fairly simple I thought but gets the job done as to raise tention when needed, however the voice acting was top notch.  Gameplay wise I gotta say that its linear and fairly simple.  The standard enemies your going after ramp slightly more in difficulty but with the bullet time its a breeze.  I do have to say that at least for me the biggest gripe I had with the game was the controls.  MP1 and 2 were butter smooth to control, this one was not.  The mouse sensitivity to much adjustments and getting used to and still to the end never fealt right.  Controls aside the game is top notch production value and fun as hell.  Pick it up, exepecially if you like Max - regardless where he is and who he fights.

Multiplayer was played a couple times, but no one is playing now... to hard to get into a game.  I did do a few rounds in the arcade mode of New York Minute.

reviewText:
This game is a lot better than I expected. As a big fan of the Remedy Max Payne games, a good chunk of the pre-release stuff was concerning me, but it all came together into a really good time. They've updated the gameplay in ways that still feel like Max Payne, and manages to be a shooter that's vastly more fun to play than the regular slow third person shooters, or twitch-based iron-sight extravaganzas.

I've been super cognizant of games that just pump endless waves of enemies, and wait for you to click on them to make them dead, lately, and it's soured a lot of otherwise good experiences (Bioshock Infinite, Space Marine, Dragon Age II). This doesn't feel like that (spare maybe one, or two instances across the whole game), and I really expected it to be. Whether it be the fun mechanics, or the encounter design as a whole, I really like how this game plays.

Also I feel like the story fits Max's character really well. While there's a definite charm to his melodrama from the previous games, Rockstar adds onto that in ways that make his character a lot more human, and helps balance things out a bit. The writing wasn't always as sharp as the Remedy games, but it surprised in other ways in equal amount.

I really like this game. You should probably play it, even if you're tired of shooters, or are turned off by the ludicrous 30GB install. It's a nice conclusion to two games that didn't really need elaborated further upon, and that's just pretty impressive to me.

reviewText:
This game was badass from the moment I pressed play. I downlaoded it cheap, with all DLCs when it was on sale and it fequently is on sale so DON'T MISS OUT, buy this god damn game when you see it for like £4.75 like I did!

It's made by Rockstar, so automatically, you should know it's going to be worthwhile. The gameplay mechanics are great. It's like GTA V's combat but a lot smoother and without the hijacking of vehicles, so it's a lot more focused. There are many guns to use, golden gun parts to collect and a hell of a lot of side objective challenge kills to do with them, which makes replaying each level valuable.

The graphics are beyond beautiful. From start to finish, the game has a very strong and persistent cinematic theme and style as well as it being narrated by the Protaganist that you play as: Max Payne. The story is full of history of his past, which you'll know about if you played the original 2 Max Payne games, and heavily influences how he acts in this game. The game has a series of choices you can make, although they do not effect the outcome of the story.

The game isn't massively long, but it's defninitely worth the money, and is seriously fun. Great graphics, great gameplay, amazing story. GET IT.

There is a multiplayer side to the game, but as far as I am aware (from rying) it isn't very active and is hard to find matches, however it is probably more active on consoles.

reviewText:
***LONG REVIEW WARNING***

I’m not sure how many times I actually asked myself “Why?” as I played Max Payne 3. “Why is he doing this?” “Why did they make this design decision?” “Why am I supposed to care?” It would go from the typical reflexive inquiries, to the borderline obsessive ones. I would continue after every stumble, extending a hand to the game, picking it up and giving it another chance to attempt walking. Eventually, I just decided to drag it until we reached the end of the road and left it there.

There is not much that makes Max Payne 3 a bad game, but rather, there is plenty that makes it a bad sequel. I’ve seen and participated in various discussions on the subject, seeing many dodgy arguments as to why people liked or hated the game. There’s a clear discontent among a certain number of people, as though something was missing in the title. Possibly the most common claim being “it’s not noir”.

And that is a claim that is as hard to support as it is to debunk. Men smarter and more qualified than either you or I have spent decades tackling this subject alone. Whether noir is an aesthetic or genre, or whether it even exists to begin with. Even among people who agree that noir exists, the criteria varies, and any “List of film noir titles” on Wikipedia or in any book wouldn’t be accurate. However, the golden age of noir died when the genre became self-aware, so now it would be more accurate to call anything written in a noir “style” neo-noir.

Claiming that either the setting or the daylight denies Max Payne 3’s right to carry the banner is dodgy at best. Many noteworthy noir titles, like White Heat, were set during the day without it being detrimental to the atmosphere. There are many other reasons to say the game lost its noir charm, but such a discussion would last for an eternity with no side being able to win. Something that can be agreed upon, though, is that if Max Payne 3 is indeed neo-noir, it is of a different ilk compared to the previous two games. Quite reasonable if you consider that movies like Sin City and American Beauty both count as neo-noir while being vastly different.

The first two games were a fusion of extreme noir melodrama and John Woo-style gunplay. It reached absurd levels story-wise, often mocking itself, but also placed a character who had rational reactions to the grimdark world around him. It’s why when you completely immerse yourself in the game, you never question Max’s actions. It never tears you away from the screen. But when you walk away and think about it, you realize just how unreasonable and silly the entire plot is.

The third game makes the mistake of toning down the setting into a more realistic one. Nothing is over the top, and there’s more emphasis on realism (as far as a third person shooter can allow). All of a sudden, we are asking questions we otherwise wouldn’t have. Our immersion breaks with every conflict between what the cutscenes imply and what the gameplay implies. Not only that, but all of a sudden, Max Payne stops being about Max and focuses on the events around him. This distinction is clear when you take into account that neither the first, nor the second game offers any sort of epilogue. It starts and ends with Max. On the other hand, Max Payne 3 offers a proper “this is what happened after Max put the gun down” scene.

This difference in atmosphere doesn’t stem only from the narrative, but also from the gameplay. Whether it was due to technical limitations, or just a savvy decision, Remedy used a minimal amount of in-game cutscenes. If Max sees an object he wants to comment on, the player needs to actually approach it by moving Max. Rockstar’s approach was to force the player’s movement, whether by cutscene or just slowing Max down due to injuries or the environment. The latter isn’t even much of an issue and is a better alternative to cutscenes, but coupled with them, it sets a much slower pace. Even trivial design decisions, like taking away the player’s control when watching TV, damages the experience.

The combat also follows this change of pace. Max Payne 3’s combat does revolve around cover, which is true to the predecessors save for the addition of a “stick to the wall” button. But it quickly becomes binary. You either have bullet-time, or you don’t. You are either at full health, or nearly dead. With infinite bullet-time jumps and only putting a cap on regular slow-mo movement, the pace changes drastically. Before, Max could jump into the action guns blazing. Now? Every single enemy is a threat, putting more emphasis on the previously mentioned increase in realism.

And then, of course, there is the actual character of Max Payne, probably the biggest problem with the latest game. Someone once told me that Max is very good at lying to himself. That’s quite an accurate statement. After all, at the end of the first game, he thought blood revenge would give him peace of mind, but as the second game showed us, it didn’t quite work out that way. However, at the end of Max Payne 2, regardless of which ending you got, Max was at peace with himself. It wasn’t something questionable like “this person is dead, everything is fine now”, but merely the culmination of all events just pushing him to a realization.

And obviously, he lied to himself again, according to Max Payne 3. This leaves a branching path, where one says that Rockstar wasn’t true to the character, while the other says they were. With the latter, one has to wonder why we should even care for the character now. There is a difference between falling on tough times and picking yourself up, and actually having two opportunities to take your life back and get at least a bittersweet ending. Payne stops being a powerful determinator and turns into this Guy With the Gun bum. A person one would find hard to care for. It would be easier for those who entered the series with this newest installment, as the predecessors become one big blur called “the dark past”, but as someone who played through both events, I find it quite difficult to ignore this kind of character development.

This is not the only issue when speaking of Max, though. His mannerisms are also drastically different. Despite the tone and rating of all games, Max rarely, if ever, swore in the first two games. I was halfway through the second game recently and I’m not quite sure if I even heard a “damn” from him. He had a sort of cold composure, dealing with his issues within himself, rather than swearing, raging and generally being openly upset about the situation. The trademark noir metaphors are also close to nonexistent now. Most of Max’s statements have become plain observations, rather than actually processing the information as he did before. No melodramatic thoughts on life beyond the occasional pearl in an ocean of dry writing.

As Payne himself says in the second game: “If you had done something differently, it wouldn’t be you, it would be someone else looking back, asking a different set of questions.” And that is what the core issue with Max Payne 3 is, in the end. It’s not about Max Payne. It’s about someone else with the same problems, dealing with them in their own way. There are many other issues we haven’t mentioned, like the highly out of place shock about the organ black market, or the redundant “Do you kill him or let him live?” prompt at the end of the game. Max Payne 3 suffers from Fallout 3 syndrome. Just how Fallout 3 was a good game, but awful Fallout, so is Max Payne 3 a good game on its own, but an abysmal addition to the series.

One only has to wonder where Remedy would have taken Max Payne 3 had they been the developers. “Max Payne’s journey through the night will continue,” say the credits of the second game. Sadly, most of the levels of Max Payne 3 were in broad daylight.

reviewText:
At first I did not like the idea of a bald Max Payne who, instead of his good-old black coat, donned a Hawaii shirt and replaced New York with South America. Some of the early screenshots were alarming and I did not want Rockstar Games to have anything to do with Remedy's well-established franchise.

However, this new Max Payne works perfectly! The story is exciting as usual - the dialog is great and as one can guess Max narrates most of the story. The graphics are stunning and even the dodge mechanism has been improved. If we dodge and Max goes into slow-mo we have to be careful with our surroundings - no more hovering Max if an object is hit in the air; Max falls and the slow-mo immediately stops. We have to be more careful and use covers more wisely.

Headshots are now almost mandatory as not long into the game can we first encounter the first vest wearing enemies. The game gradually gets more difficult, in fact, if it is too difficult (if the player dies too often) the AI provides us with extra painkillers to have a successful run after loading the last checkpoint.

The game features a long and excellent campaign with collectibles and those seeking extra challenge can complete the game on higher difficulties which, just like in the predecessor games, get unlocked only after walkthroughs.

I heard the multiplayer option is also very good. I'm not sure if there can be many players online these days but the game's campaign alone worth the purchase.
voteText: 56 of 74 people (76%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
What you think about this game greatly depends on how you look at it.
If you look at it as sequel to the Max Payne and Max Payne 2 it turns out rather bad in term of story, theme and general feeling, as instead of typical dark and mysterious noir always happening in the shadows, you get story in the middle of Brasil, in the middle of the day.
However, if you look at it as completely independent game it is sweet and satisfacting. Well, limitation to weapons sucks a bit, but game is fast-paced, interesting, killing is cool, shootouts are fun, levels are well designed, you get intelligent propotion between playing and watching cutscenes, being the fillers.
Like before, Max Payne 3 has 3 Chapters, around 5 missions each. Small change to the system was letting the player take painkillers moment before dying.
Going for the storyline: Long story short, it's about ex-cop trying to sort his life and find redemption in a little bit different line of job, as private security. Knowing it's about Max, you can expect some pesimism and failing on the way.

I recommend this game, because even if it's no longer night-dark, it's still pesimist-dark, still looking for change, still trying to bury the past, still awesome gameplay and nice feeling. Game is greatly made.

(Please note I ommited mentioning multiplayer, it's good, but Max Payne is about single player!)

reviewText:
TLDR VERDICTMax Payne 3 is an excellent experience that blends together great third person shooter gameplay with a compelling narrative all backed up by Rockstars detailed world design. It is an absolute must buy on sale if you haven't played it already.

FULL REVIEW BELOW
There are two kinds of people: ones that are trying to build their future and ones that are trying to rebuild their past." - Max Payne

Max Payne is a retired NYPD Detective. It's been almost 10 years since the traumatic events of the first two games and Max is just about done with life. That is until all of a sudden Max is offered a job as a bodyguard for one of Sao Paulo's most prestigious families. An easy gig...

This review is written from the perspective of a fan of the previous Max Payne games as well as third-person shooters and story driven games in general.

GAMEPLAY AND DESIGNOn a purely functional level

It seems that Rockstar has done this to create more consistency between gameplay and cinematics for a smoother experience as Max will actually be carrying the weapons you're playing with during cutscenes. The guns themselves are all unique with varying stats that will suit different enemy types and situations. The health system is based on painkiller pickups like in previous games with no regenerating health mechanic. There are a lot of difficulty options available to suit both casual gamers and those after a punishing challenge.\n\nThe game is designed as a largely linear corridor third person shooter. reviewText:
Max Payne 3 is what happens when you take barely-competent devs, give them a classic, well-liked franchise, force them to play Uncharted 2 for hours on end, and set them free to make a game so bloated by bad decisions that it's hard to see the good through the bad.

I went in wanting to like Max Payne 3. I'd known most of the story, but I was still hoping maybe, just maybe, there'd be some redeeming quality about it.
Nope. The story was asinine, insulting to my intelligence, and essentially serves to completely take Max Payne away from his character, his motivations, and everything that he stood for. When it's not taking control away from you to force an ugly cutscene down your throat, it's told through internal monologues, the kind that made Max Payne and Max Payne 2 interesting to play through.
Here, however, they forget that Max Payne isn't an action here with a sailor's mouth and multiple personality disorder, leading you to wonder if maybe Max Payne had been replaced by Bruce Willis in a B-movie nobody watched.

I do give some nods to presentation, but they're reluctant. The graphics are top-notch, the environments look great and are varied nicely, but the screen effects, camera angles, and effects in Last Stand are distracting and ugly.
Some of the lighting effects and reflections were absolutely astounding though, and I do give Rockstar the most credit here: the game looks great. A shame.

If the game played as good as it looked, I'd be a little bit happier, but it just doesn't. Max Payne and Max Payne 2 worked because they were unrealistic and they knew it. Max Payne 3 is a weird mesh of realism and surrealism that doesn't work at all. You bullettime dodge and it all goes slow-mo while you shoot dudes in the head. That's not realistic.
Yet seconds later you hit a wall, bounce off, and take three seconds to get up. That is realistic, but it's not fun and it takes you completely out of your groove. It's a bad way for Rockstar to show off their admittedly decent physics engine, and it serves to both look dumb and play worse, which is a good feat.

The gunplay is top-tier. It hits hard, it feels good, and it sounds better. The enemy tiers are almost straight-ripped from Uncharted, though, and shooting helmets off guys, which forces you to headshot them multiple times, serves as an annoyance -- especially when they will one-hit you from across the room if even part of your body sticks out.

The sound design is a puzzling mix of beautiful effort put into sound effects and gun sounds and complete laziness with the soundtrack. The music is completely boring aside from the remixed MP1 theme and I struggle to recall any music I can remember that wasn't insidiously grating to my senses and intelligence. (Strip club, I am looking at you.)
There is one moment towards the end of the game where there's a good song playing and you're shooting dudes in the face and it all flows pretty nicely, but it doesn't make up for the lack of other memorable tracks.

Max Payne 3 feels like a betrayal to everything Remedy did with the prior Max Payne games. It turns Max from a sympathetic, hard-luck character into a mass murdering, suicidal drunk old man who somehow still pulls off Nathan Drake-like stunts. It pulls ideas and concepts from other games wholesale (Rockstar must really like Naughty Dog) and shoehorns them in with little regard for gameplay or story. The story tries to make you think, but it actually tells you what to think and then it repeats it a few times for good measure, then ends in a completely dumb way that contradicts the entire rest of the game.

Avoid at all costs if you've played MP1 and MP2 and liked them at all. If you're just starting the Max Payne series and you feel you must play this game, play it before the other two.

reviewText:
Fantastic game, 9/10.

Story: almost half of the game is consisted of narrative cinematics, giving you an insight of the situation and presenting the though processes of Max and his internal struggles as he uncovers a series of crude betrayals. voice acting is captivating and dialogues are well written.

Gameplay: brutal. One second you are watching a cinematic and a second later you are thrown into a room giving you 5 seconds to headshot 10 people or you die a merciless death. Unlike most modern shooters, there is no regenerative health, forcing you to be very aware of your situations and any reckless moves will cost you greatly. The AIs aren't necessarily the smartest, but they will try their best to flank you and shotgun you to the face. Even with his Bullet-Time skills, Max never felt too overpowered and still requires you to take cover and plan your moves accordingly.

Presentation: The game takes place in Brazil, and interestingly the developers decided to keep the game authentic and make all natives speak Spanish instead of broken English, and just like Max, your inability to understand what the people are saying makes you feel foreign and secluded, which makes the game that much more immersive.

Thoughts: for a 30+ GB installation, this is actually a rather short game, with just a bit over 12 hours of campaign. The gameplay is fairly linear and there really isn't much to explore. there are also occasional rag doll problems where you'll see Max flail his arm around and not being able to shoot anyone, giving you a frustrating death. Overall this game is incredibly well polished and enjoyable, highly recommended.

reviewText:
Max Payne 3 does many things well, but it's severely crippled by several design flaws.

The worst offender: the cover system. It breaks the game entirely. The first two Max Payne games forced you to be constantly on the move to win, always running and gunning in order to move forward. You were rewarded for taking risks. MP3, by constrast, rewards you for crouching and hiding, forcing you to jump from cover to cover with brief snaps of bullet time. This is especially evident on harder difficulties, where you are often instantly killed just for poking your head out. This KILLS the fun that you should be having. Cover systems are all the rage nowadays and they can be done right, but this is just about the worst implementation I've seen.

The comic book style unfolding of the story is also gone, and for the worse. Instead we get blurred-out color-saturated cutscenes. LOTS of cutscenes. Seems like every door between shootouts is another cutscene. They get old fast, and the story and characters are not interesting enough to keep them from dragging.

MP3 can be fun at times, but I would not recommend it to anyone who has played the first two games - you will be disappointed.

reviewText:

Do you want to do that over and over again for 10-12 hours and feel like a badass? Sure you do.
Also, Max Payne is an alcoholic, he practically pours whiskey on his morning cornflakes whilst reading Charles Bukowski poetry yet he is as accurate as an Olympic sharpshooter so y'know.....alcoholism rocks.

Chow Yun Fat simulator 2012.

9/10.

reviewText:
+ Gunplay, movement, camera angles, and slow-motion effects are all solidly implemented, staying true to the series' staples
+ Cover system was simple to use and functional in practice
+ Slow-motion kill-cams (after killing the last enemy in an area) are a great touch, and make the combat itself feel cinematic
+ Game boasts some quality voice-acting; not the best I've heard, but it certainly is above average
+ Visible wounds look great on enemy models
+ The soundtrack was great when used, though it only stands out in a few areas of the game
+ If you are lost, the next objectives are narrated by the protagonist, which negates the use of invasive objective markers, and it fits into the atmosphere of the game (being that it is already being narrated)
+ Enemies fall in a realistic manner
+ Melee executions are cinematic and satisfying
+ Plot was predictable, but had more depth than expected; Max Payne's character was a good performance for the kind of character he is, and tied everything together neatly
+ Multiplayer is basic, but very fun and entertaining
+ While the level designs were fairly linear, the textures struck me as slightly above-average for the year of release, and when considering that third-person games tend to have less focus on close-up textures (I think this was because the game uses rendered graphics for cutscenes; works well, nonetheless)

- Social Club DRM is annoying and time-consuming to get working properly; if you are adamantly anti-invasive DRM then this may not be a good fit for you
- Stiff animations
- While the voice-acting is overall well-done, there were some problems where the voices lost sync with the scenes
- Visible wounds look TERRIBLE on the protagonist
- Inordinate reliance on cut-scenes, which can make for an uneasy flow to the gameplay (in addition, every minor cut-scene switches your weapon back to your pistol, making you constantly cycle through to weapons you already intended to use)
- Poor variation in weaponry; for a game that is focused on gunplay, I expected more than nine or ten firearms throughout the campaign
- Very poor lighting effects

reviewText:
Remedy’s first two Max Payne titles were a real rarity in the lurid world of action games. They wore their nostalgia for film noire and Hong Kong cinema on their sleeves, but were also cuttingly self-aware, pointing out the more ludicrous aspects of their own genre with a protagonist who could sometimes scarcely believe the situation he was in. Max Payne liberally broke the fourth wall in the first two games but when the jibes were over, the titles served as some of the best third person shooters of their era.

Max Payne 3, then, focuses on Max as a drugged out, liquored up mess, and this is fitting. Max Payne 3 isn’t a bad game by any stretch but it has clearly sacrificed some of its wit and soul on the path back to prominence. Remedy is no longer at the helm, which leaves publisher Rockstar to develop the game internally…and all that it implies.

Max 3 starts promising enough. Max has apparently fled New Jersey for a private security gig in Brazil, working with an old friend from the police academy named Passos. Max and Passos are charged with guarding a prominent Brazilian politician and his family, and the easy paychecks and opulent atmosphere have allowed Max to sink even deeper into his alcohol and painkiller habits. Rockstar may like to spend way too much time watching Max get absolutely trashed on vicodin and whiskey in his apartment, but that wouldn’t make for a very exciting game, so it isn’t long before the family is attacked by paramilitary thugs and Max and Passos are off on an ill-conceived hostage hunt.

The gameplay, particularly the movement and shooting feel much tighter than GTA4, and this has a lot to do with Rockstar apparently imitating the first two Max Payne games. Aside from Max only being able to carry one set of dual wielded handguns and maybe a rifle or shotgun on the side instead of an entire military arsenal, the aiming, shooting and acrobatics are replicated almost perfectly in the new game. Max also doesn’t have recharging health; you have to grab painkillers and slam them back when his HUD silhouette starts filling up with red, just like the old days. The first few levels make you feel right at home, but then things start to fall apart when the difficulty ramps up quickly.

The problem is that Rockstar tries to implement current shooter mechanics—big emphasis on cover combat, limited ammo reserved, huge set piece rooms filled with enemies—with the game design from the old Max Payne games and it just doesn’t work very well, especially if you try to play Max 3 like Max 1 or 2. If you do a graceful slow-mo gun ballet dive out of cover, expect to get shot to pieces. If you happen to bump another piece of cover or some other extraneous object, it automatically kills your slow-mo, and this is a common occurrence considering how cluttered the environment gets later on. Focus-diving just isn’t a good tactic anymore and the only time you’ll be able to use it effectively is during scripted events.

The mix of Max’s classic bullet-time acrobatics and the rote, modern waist-high cover gunplay is a clumsy one at best. I often found myself hunkering behind cover, leaving my time-slowing focus to languish. As the game got harder and enemies became inexplicably tougher I was even less inclined to dive out and instigate a bullet ballet; the only way it could end is Max clumsily landing in a heap, scrambling to his feet and rushing back to cover, taking several unnecessary bullets to his hide in the process.

Franchise disappointments aside, once I got to about the halfway point I was genuinely enjoying Max Payne 3. It was easy to get into the groove of the gunplay and unlike many other cover based shooters, Max 3 didn’t feel stale for quite a few levels. But a game is more than its gameplay, especially with something like Max Payne—the game’s story needed to stand on its own and this is where Max 3 falters again.

At first the storytelling and presentation are great—if anything Rockstar knows how to make a good first impression. The cutscenes are done in a dynamic comic-panel cutaway style, with various frames sliding into place and important or witty dialog superimposed with eye-catching subtitle boxes. It really makes the sometimes overlong, load-time disguising cutscenes bearable, at least on the first play through, and lends the game both a traditional film noire attitude and a vague South American cinema sensibility as well.

About a third of the way through, Max develops a serious case of cutscene stupidity for the sole purpose of progressing the plot. I’m not talking about when he shaves his head and I don’t want to spoil anything, but a little past the head-shaving the game starts to get a bit too ridiculous and just keeps going farther into double-cross conspiracy insanity, as Rockstar’s crime dramas have a tendency to do. This is really aggravating because when Max isn’t being inordinately stupid I really enjoyed his dry, sardonic personality, and his sarcastic quips never get old. He just doesn’t react to the insanity by breaking the fourth wall.

Max Payne 3 runs into the same problem I’ve had with a couple other Rockstar games—instead of the game laughing with you and winking about its own ludicrousness, it plays things so dark and extreme that it becomes an unintentional parody of itself. So many people get ventilated and Max gets shot, beaten and shredded so many times in the first few levels that you can’t possibly take the hard boiled plot seriously.

Of course the Rockstar pedigree applies to the game’s production values. The RAGE engine is definitely showing its age but if you can get past the somewhat janky facial animations, the rest of the game is gorgeous. It starts off a little muddy and generic, but that has more to do with how overdone “gritty” visuals are this generation. Once Max gets out into some of the more exotic locales and starts flashing back to the dingy streets of Jersey the visuals really start to shine, and they stay almost sensory-overload good until the credits roll. The slow-mo effects can be breathtaking, with bullets whizzing toward the camera after just barely missing Max, and each firefight is capped off with a bullet-trajectory killcam that highlights the last lethal shot, focusing in on a goon’s perforated gut or fractured face.

The sound design is equally good. James McCaffrey reprises his role as Max Payne and realistically pulls off the character as older, number and more jaded, but with a killer edge that comes back out when needed. The plot’s writing may be kind of messy but Max’s dialog is as good as ever, even if it got less snarky and more doom n’ gloom as they game wore on. In any case McCaffrey just nails the delivery every time, even making wry justifications whenever you pick up yet another bottle of pills.

I know I’ve been saying this for a while, but Rockstar just doesn’t know how to mix humor and serious drama. They always end up with a whiny, mopey anti-hero cast against a world full of ♥♥♥♥ jokes, cliché gangster parodies and other assorted “mature” humor and it all comes off like some angsty fanfic written by a 13 year old trying to look cool. With a character and world as strong as Max Payne’s some of that pretense is mitigated, but it’s still clear that the storytellers at Rockstar have trouble growing up. That said, I’m optimistic. The story of Max Payne 3 is ultimately a fresh start for the character. Hopefully, after a somewhat rocky return to slow-mo dives and epic gun fights, the Max Payne series has a brighter future ahead.

Max Payne 3 is a real love-hate relationship. Just when the solo story is getting good, the gameplay will get clunky, the slow-mo will go unused or Max will do something dumb. Max 3 is a rocky return to form but at least Max Payne is back and dodging bullets again.

reviewText:
Max Payne 3

I'm a huge fan of the Max Payne franchise, I loved the whole dark and gritty feeling, so I was really excited about this game, and I wasn't disappointed at all, I finished it twice because I loved it so much!
and now, I've decided to write a review about it and share my thoughts about this great game!

Story
So, if you don't have a clue about who is Max Payne... you ought to be ashamed!
I'll just start from this game, so, after the last game, Max left the police force and settled in a New Jersey, where he was just drinking himself to death and been haunted by the loss of his family,
one day, while he was drinking a friend finds him in the bar, and offers him a job, to protect a well known family in Rio De Janeiro, Brazil, he accepts the job, and leaves USA to protect the family.
And from here the story twists and turns...

Graphics
The graphics are amazing imo, really good, they've thought of everything (Rockstar), even the smallest details,
the animations are crazy good, the effects of the bullet-time is sweet!... I've nothing to add, really the graphics are sweet!

Gameplay
Max Payne is a third-person shooter, and the first Max Payne where the first to introduce the Bullet-Time feature, and so, it's also in this game, and they've taken the game to the next level,
I mean it, everything, you can jump to each side while the effect is on, you can move from cover to cover, you can blind-fire, and there's also a slow-motion effect when you kill dudes (like Fallout 3, Skyrim etc)... everything you look in a third-person shooter, Max Payne 3 got!
and my favourite one is that when you prone you actually roll over and the player turns 360 degrees to maintain his sight on target, I found that really nice and making me feel like they've thought of everything in the game.
now, I heard from people that actually didn't like the game because of the long cut-scenes, I really don't understand this, cause the game itself is story driven and the cut-scenes are a must!
the story it self is amazing, and the cut-scenes are just like a movie, Rockstar knows how to make this kinda games, from GTA to Red Dead Redemption, L.A. Noire and Max Payne.
I loved the gameplay, it's full of action and fun!

Conclusion
I LOVE THIS GAME!
The game is well built! they've put thought of every small detail, and just made it perfect!
The gameplay is fun and full of action! and I just couldn't get enough of it! the single player is long and delivers a movie-like story, with twists and turns, it took me about 13 hours or so to complete the game,
The graphics are amazing! had no bugs at all, the game worked fluently with no lags at all, and I had GTS 8800 320MB GPU, which wasn't the best at the time I played it.
I can really go on and on praising this game, and I really think the game deserves it, Rockstar made an excellent game, they maintained the feeling of the original games and just made it even better!
If you didn't play this game at all, put it in the top of your list, and if you already played it and stopped, give it another go!
for me, I'm waiting for the next Max Payne to come out, I really hope they're making one :)

reviewText:
TL:DR? See Conclusion
INTRODUCTION:Max Payne 3 is the latest installment in the popular and award winning Max Payne franchise. Unlike the first two titles however, Max Payne 3 is fully developed and published by Rockstar Games whose notable works include the popular Grand Theft Auto (GTA) franchise.

Once again the player steps into the shoes of Max Payne, a former New York City Detective who, after the events of the first two games, went on a downward spiral both in career and personal life. Now, 9 years since the last game, Max retired from his job as a detective and now works as private security contractor in Brazil. Things were going well (aside from the Pain Killer addiction and Alcoholism), until he's caught in another conspiracy, this time, involving gang violence, a corrupt police department and the kidnapping of the members of a famous and wealthy family.

PROS:+ Gorgeous Graphics and Visuals (Except for the Filters, See Cons)
+ Great new Setting (Brazil)
+ Scenic locations and flashbacks (Brazil and New Jersey)
+ Great sounds, voice acting and soundtrack
+ Good story writing (albeit a bit more generic compared to the last two games, it's still very well written)
+ Improved gameplay (added a new cover system and 'last man standing' among other things)
+ Large weapon variety
+ Collectibles that reward the player with either additional story or improved weapon upgrades
+ Intense and action packed combat

CONS:- Excessive cutscenes
- Extremely long loading times that make some cutscenes technically unskippable (“Still Loading” after 3 minutes of cutscene I want to skip is unacceptable, specially on an SSD)
- Excessive use of Filters that can cause headaches
- Unnecessary Multiplayer
- Rockstar Games Social Club
- MASSIVE 35 Gigabyte Storage requirement (probably because of Con #1 see above)

OTHER NOTE:- Linear storytelling is FINE, its a good way to tell a narrative story in a directed pace. Not every game needs to be open world people.

CONCLUSION:GREAT GAME and I liked it. As a Max Payne fan, I was pleased with how Max Payne 3 wraps up the sad and emotionally crushing life that Max has lived. The Graphics were gorgeous with a scenic new location in São Paulo, Brazil. The story was a bit more generic than the deep emotional roller-coaster of the first 2 games but nonetheless, it's still very well written. Gameplay was improved by adding new weapons, last-man-standing, and a cover system to boot. The game does suffer from a very long loading time, excessive use of special effects filters and long cutscenes which made the game size a whooping 35 gigabyte.

All in all, Max Payne 3 is a GREAT GAME and a GOOD SEQUEL / Franchise Finale. I can recommend this game as it is in full price but if you are, get the regular Max Payne 3 and not the complete version. The DLCs are all for multiplayer and skins with no additional story or missions. With that said, the game does go on Sale very often.

reviewText:
I loved Max Payne 1 and 2 on PC in the early 2000's. I didn't buy those games or this game to play multiplayer.

Here is my experience with Max Payne 3:

1. Download over 36 gigabytes for a single game.
2. Forced to create a Rockstar Games Social Club account. Another worthless DRM system to which I must give my email address and create yet another password.
3. Finally start playing the game. Graphics look decent.
4. Sit through minutes and mintes of cut scenes that cannot be skipped. I finally get to shoot some people. Cover mechanic and bullet time are fun. The game basically works by locking you into an area until you shoot all enemies. Open the next door, cut scene, shoot dudes, next door, cut scene, shoot dudes. And wow, are these cut scenes melodramatic. Give me a break.
5. Then the game crashes during a cut scene. I restart the game, play the area again, and it crashes at the same spot. Update my Nvidia driver. Game crashes in the same spot.

Forget this game. I'm done. Rockstar ruined Max Payne.

reviewText:
Difficulty: Just Right
The Bottom Line: Masterpiece/Superb
Score: 9.5

Note: This Game Been Tried Out And Reviewed In Offline Mode or On Another Steam Account And Or Consoles.

I Am a huge fan of the max payne series,and was eagerly waiting for the 3rd part since 2003.While I was eagerly anticipating for it.

After nearly a decade, Max Payne has returned to us and it is largely a success. Max is now in Brazil working as a bodyguard for a rich family and while he isn't doing that he is binge drinking and pushing the overwrought narrative of man with a dark and haunted past just trying to make a living shooting a seemingly endless number of thugs in the coolest ways possible. In short, it is a lot of fun

Overall: Max Payne 3 is a great action game, but some flaws prevent it from being the classic I hoped for, Gamers who enjoy an intense action shooting game with fun mechanics, good sound, great graphics, and a strong well written narrative, Would be making a mistake to Skip Max Payne 3.

reviewText:
Max Payne 3 is a noir journey to the heart of the protagonist. The story is unfold upon the player's eye with convoluted and deep story telling by the protagonist, which is getting older and struggles with addiction and the ghost of loved ones. Max Payne 3 proves its audience that there can be noir settings other than snow and night.

In Max Payne 3, you can see and feel not only story-wise but gameplay-wise that Max is getting old, he no longer can dodge bullets and get up as quickly he used to do. Getting up takes time, Max dives awkwardly and stays down on the ground and ocasionally would hit walls. These are all story details that are blended into the gameplay masterfully. It doesn't breaks the frantic shooting action in any way, but also gives you a new way to play Max Payne and makes you be careful about making mistakes.

The action is pretty well paced as far the story and the gameplay goes. There are a good set of quiet segments and frantic bullet spraying all over the place as well.

But the star of the show of this game is Rockstar's SUPERB physics. Shooting guns never felt this good before. The impact physics is amazing and fun at the same time. Each gun has a different impact and power depending on the direction and range you shoot. I'm astounished by the physics which along the story is the selling point of this game.

Multiplayer is dead, which is a shame, I'd like to know how it feels like to use bullet time on a multiplayer game.

I really like the setting. Rockstar's R&D dept. did a pretty damn good job on researching Brazil's favelas, police forces and street gangs in a way that felt realistic and made sense even for a Brazilian. The voice acting plays a major role in the Brazil's impersonation aspect; The brazilian accent is perfect and the english doesn't seem awkward at all. They did a pretty good job on voice acting.

My only complaints goes to the railshooter sections. Railshoot doesn't fit in a Max Payne game. At all. It doesn't feel clunky, but it's boring when you'd rather be jumping and shooting bad guys.

Overall, Max Payne 3 is IMO the best game in the series. Major overhauls at gameplay elements, daring settings and deep story will suck you into this noir journey in Brazil and New Jersey.

reviewText: This is a 12-hour long cutscene with occasional third-person shooter segments and grind-fest multiplayer. It has almost none of what made the first two Max Payne games so great: the phenomenal storytelling, gripping plots, noir styling. The one thing it *does* have that the original two did is solid third-person shooter gameplay with cool bullet time mechanics. Only problem is that out of the 12 hours the story goes, maybe 45 minutes to an hour and a half of it is actual gameplay. The style in this game isn't noir. It's like the movie Man on Fire
date: which on its own is actually a really good movie, but here it comes across as a bad crossover fanfiction. Replacing the noir style with Hollywood action/thriller was a terrible idea. It constantly feels like the game's trying to trigger epileptic episodes by having bright colors and distortions as well as random text from the dialogue (much of which is completely pointless to emphasize so why they bother with it is beyond me) flash all over the screen. The plot itself is rather stupid and has basically nothing to do with Max Payne; frankly they should've just made the protagonist someone else. Ultimately it insults me as a Max Payne fan that they didn't care at all about what made Max Payne 1 & 2 so special, and even outright spit in my face with segments like the graveyard sequence. It also insults me as a reasonably intelligent person because the plot is so incredibly thin and predictable, yet the game keeps acting like it's some masterful example of the art form. When there actually *is* gameplay, it's pretty decent, though you'll find the camera often spazzes out due to the cover in the environment, causing you to die because you can't get an angle on anything (which is especially annoying during the last stand" thing the game does). Multiplayer's tolerable once you get to rank 4 and can create your own classes
recommended: but it's punishingly unfair to new players and there's barely anyone playing it so I advise not even bothering.\n\nIn summary

reviewText:
IntroductionMax Payne 3 is a third person, action shooter with a very addicting bullettime mechanic and a good story to boot.

Developed by Rockstar Studios in 2012, this game is no doubt a wonderful expansion to the already amazing series, and is a contender for one of the best in its genre.

Plot DetailsProtagonist
The game series has you playing as (you guessed it) Max Payne, a pill addict and someone who should already be dead due to physical trauma. If you haven't played any of the previous games, you won't quite know what he went through, but take it from me, this guy is hard as nails. After losing his wife, (and every other main woman in his life) he goes on an endless killing spree to 'right the wrong'; or so he'd think.

In this game, your journey takes you to Brazil, nine years after the events of Max Payne 2. Max Payne, a middle aged man by now, is a tired, booze addict who simply wants a life free of action. If you ever hated pills and booze then this guy is going to ♥♥♥♥ you off. Max Payne consistently makes questionable choices and many of them don't seem to go his way, but if there's anything I'd commend is his persistence and commitment to whatever he's doing. As far as badass protagonists go, he's definitely close to the top of the list. Max Payne continually makes almost poetic comments about various situations he encounters, bringing an element of depth to a man who ruthlessly guns down those in his way.

Story
In brazil, Max Payne wants an easy job, to get away from the horrors of the past. A friend of his, Passos, enlisted him for an 'easy' job of protecting the Branco family. Without revealing much, you'll discover that nothing is ever easy in the world of Max Payne. Almost anything that can go wrong, usually does. The story is pretty believable if you ignore the fact that he goes up against so many enemies with various high powered weapons, and is captivating enough for you to continue playing it.

In this story, nothing comes easy to Max, and you're sure to endure many painful/frustrating moments as you see just how human this guy is. But if you like a story of a man fighting till the very end, this is one hell of a treat.

GameplayMax Payne's shooting is pretty satisfying. Headshots with most guns will instantly kill a target, while body shots may simply knock them down for a while. Some enemies will try to shoot at you if they aren't killed, incentivizing the player to ensure they are killed. I liked the fact that enemies were so dynamic, as they would try to take a shot at the player from wherever they could. They utilized cover pretty well, and would sometimes not even lean their body out to take a shot. As the enemies got tougher, their body armor and intelligence got better as well. Sometimes they would jump between cover slowly inching their way towards you, sometimes they would simply rush you down. It all depended on the type of enemy faced.

Using the bullet time mechanic, combat was always fun. Seeing the bullets whizz right past my face as I took out five enemies in a single dive was definitely satisfying. One welcome feature was the ability to shoot on the ground after I had done a bullet jump. This was helpful because there were some areas of cover that would be too low for a crouch but just right on the ground. Sadly the lack of a prone button was disappointing, as there's no reason why he couldn't have that.

The shooting recticle was a very simple dot in the middle of the screen, which incentivized proper aiming. This game, even more than previous games, focused a lot on utilizing cover and bullettime mechanics, as enemies could shred you in almost no time at all. Avoiding damage was the best way to progress through levels, but even so I found myself dying at various points and I enjoyed the feeling of satisfaction beating the enemies. Healing up was done through the signature painkillers, which I'm currently sick of (please no more painkillers, just let me die). Dying didn't totally leave you in a pickle, as you'd slowly gain more benefits to make a retry easier every time you died; more painkillers, ammo, etc. Overall, gameplay was quite fun, but definitely had a lot of challenge to it, perfect for people who are tired of the easy-mode shooters out there.

VisualsMax Payne 3's visuals were both good and bad. The visuals were well done, and the environments were impressive enough, but for the love of all that is holy, STOP THE CHROMATIC ABBERATION. This cinematic effect, used no doubt for a 'drunken' feel, was the bane of my existence in this game. It's terribly annoying on the eyes and it needs to stop, like yesterday. That alone ruined a lot of the game for me.

AudioI actually liked the music and voice-overs in MP3. I think enough effort was put into this aspect for it to warrant a thumbs up. Some aspects didn't exactly stand out, but I guess everything fulfilled its purpose well enough.

MultiplayerSadly, multiplayer is dead, with one group out there dedicated to playing more Max Payne 3 multiplayer.

Summary & ConclusionMax Payne 3 is a brilliant 3rd person shooter, with unique mechanics and a thrilling story. The audio and visuals are nothing to scoff at, but where this game shines is it's core gameplay and badass protagonist. Though the chromatic aberration and drug overdose nearly killed me inside, Max Payne 3 is a game you'll regret not playing.

9/10 Worth a Buy.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
Max Payne 3 is the official sequel to Max Payne and May Payne 2 by a different developer, plays exactly the same way, but doesnt feel the same. The third part of the trilogy drops the praised Noir flair and replaces it with a stupified storyline, a bitter and permanently angry mainprotagonist, characters you dont really care about, and broad daylight battles in the slums and swamps of Brazil with a ludicrous number of human enemies to kill. You basically run from one flashy, overstylized cutscene to the next one. Oh, and in between you shoot stuff.

Dont get me wrong. The action is fantastic! I would even say magnificent. Rockstar definitely know what they are doing, by showing us how to create a playable action movie and throwing the player in a constant adrenaline rush with an alarmingly intense addiction rate. The staging of the levels is over the top. Gameplay is all about style and being the personified one man army. But besides this aspect and the pretty awesome graphics, the game has not much else too offer. That said, I only played the singleplayer. And even finishing the game a month ago, I cant remember sh*t about the story. Maybe the multiplayer makes up for that.

Le conclusio:
You like fast and pure action games on hollywood blockbuster rating with lots of bullets and targets to shoot? Get this game for, I dont know, 5-10 bugs maximum. You will be entertained, guaranteed.
You loved the first two Max Payne's because of the Noir flair, the plot, the characters, and you are now looking forward to experience something similiar? Dont get this game.

Same same but different, I guess...

santi

reviewText:
So I guess I'd become what they wanted me to be, a killer. Some rent-a-clown with a gun who puts holes in other bad guys. Well that's what they had paid for, so in the end that's what they got. Say what you want about Americans but we understand capitalism. You buy yourself a product and you get what you pay for.

Story Nine years after Max Payne 2, Max finds himself drinking away his sorrow after he got fired from the NYPD, for consorting with the criminal Mona Sax. He has developed a drinking problem and his addiction to painkillers has gotten worse. He has moved back to where he lived with his wife and daughter: Hoboken, New Jersey. Max gets into a confrontation with the son of the local mob boss Anthony Demarco. And an old friend who claims to have been on the police academy with Max, Raul Passos,  finds him at the bar, hoping to recruit him for a private security job in South-America. Max resists, but after he kills the son of Anthony Demarco, he has no choice but to flee from his home.

Gameplay Of all the three Max Payne games, Max Payne 3 has arguably the best gameplay of them all. The controls are very solid, and the gameplay can be very addictive. The good old bullet-time is back, and works mostly the same as it always has. Instead of being able to carry your whole arsenal with you, like in Max Payne 1 and 2, You can carry up to three weapons. Two small ones, and one big one. If you want to duel-wield your small weapons, you have to drop your big weapon. This is actually very fun in my opinion, this way you have to use every gun at least once. Max Payne 3 has fourteen chapters instead of three parts with each seven to nine chapters. Max Payne 3 is also way more linear than its predecessors. This seems like it has less content, but Max Payne 3 is the longest of the bunch, which will take the average gamer around thirteen hours to complete.

Multiplayer Next to the story mode, Max Payne 3 has a surprisingly fun multiplayer mode. You can create your own character to use in various different modes. Or if you bought the DLC, you can play fan favorites in the free for all deathmatch mode, like Vladimir Lem, Valerie Winterson, Vinnie Gognitti, Mona Sax and more. The game also has a multiplayer survival mode, called Dead Men Walking. In this co-op mode, you play as Max or Raul Passos, and must fend of waves of enemies, which can be very addictive and fun.

Conclusion Max Payne 3 is a different kind of game than its predecessors. The gameplay is way more solid, and the change of setting may anger a lot of fans. But this change is very welcome in my opinion and works really well. The story has as in every Max Payne game a few twists and turns, which are still very well done. Many fans say that Max Payne 3 has gone away from its roots too much, but it's still a game about Max Payne, and it's still a very good game with a very interesting and dark story.

8/10

reviewText:
Max Payne 3 is another wonderful experience provided by the studio, Rockstar Games. In this game, you play as a washed up NYPD Detective, never being able to leave his horrid past after his wife and daughter are murdered. To start, you do not need to play the other Max Payne games to know what is going on in the third installment; everything you need to know is detailed throughout the game’s narrative.

The game focuses on intense shootouts and bullet-time, most of the encounters in the game will end in blood soaked rooms, riddled with bullet holes, as tiles chip off the walls and crash to the ground. Max Payne 3 is a beautiful game, with visuals that can barely be rivaled by other games currently on the market. Contrary to Rockstar’s history, Max Payne 3 is a wonderful PC port, putting their last port, GTA IV, to shame. Max Payne 3 runs on all sorts of systems and doesn’t require the most up to date equipment to run. Sadly, Max Payne 3’s multiplayer experience is a bit flawed, as it is plagued with Russians (Like Dota 2) and hackers (most of which are Russians).

Hopefully with more patches, the amount of Reds ruining multiplayer will decrease.
In the end, Max Payne 3 is an experience that all gamers should enjoy, one of the best games of 2012.

reviewText:
Rewriting my review since the old one did not do it justice.
Max Payne 3, the sequel to the fantastic 2003 Max Payne 2: The Fall Of Max Payne, is an entertaining, thrilling, amazing experience from start to finish.

Story:  Set in São Paulo, the protagonist, Max Payne, is a retired ol' NYCPD cop. Max’s diet consists of liquor and pain killers to make him forget the sorrows of what had happened to him and his deceased family. Desperate to get out of his pitiful condition, he takes a job as a body guard for a rich Brazilian business man named Fabricas Branco. But it turns out that it isn't an easy job after all, when Fabiana, Fabricas' wife, is kidnaped.
The plot is full of conspiracies and sick twists and huge amazing set pieces and in the end... it pays off, it is one of the best stories told in a video game.

Gameplay:  Simple yet incredibly fun, with a huge array of weapons to choose from, you shoot, jump and make amazing Matrix" type tricks
date: gunplay is refined and perfect.\n\nGraphics:  The game is beautiful
recommended: from art direction to meshes and polygons. Animations are one of the best around. Surprisingly
hoursPlayed: the game is very well optimized and it utilizes many PC specific features such as DirectX11. (which is weird for a Rockstar game)\n\nSound:  Voice acting is top notch with James McCaffrey returning as Max Payne. The soundtrack is AWESOME
voteText: don’t believe me? Just check out "Tears by Health" on YouTube
helpfulPercent: you'll love it!\n\nMultiplayer:  for the first time ever in a Max Payne game
votesHelpful: a multiplayer mode is included. Many people were skeptical about it but as it turns out... they were all wrong. This fun creative experience has all the singleplayer abilities such as Bullet Time and Shootdodge in it
votesTotal:
which makes it stand out from the crowd. it is fast paced and (sometimes) chaotic and balanced.

Overall it was my personal 2012 GOTY and it still is.
10/10"

reviewText:
I only tried playing the Single Player mode.

Unpolished and full of bugs, painfully one-dimensional characters, a story that is one giant cliche directly inspired by B action movies.

Try walking forward -> Cinematic cutscene of you walking
Try opening a door -> Cinematic cutscene of you opening a door
Try running -> Cinematic cutscene of you running
Try stopping -> Max Payne tells you to hurry! you gotta catch the next completely pointless cinematic cutscene

And did I mention cutscenes are unskippable? Actual gameplay time is a fraction of the time you spend staring at pointless cutscenes.

Despite my best efforts I couldn't get myself to finish it, this game killed Max Payne for me.
