reviewText:
It's been a long time, Max.

Max Payne 1 and 2 were high water marks for third person shooters, the first for its gunplay and style and the second for pairing those elements with a tight story focus.  The second game wrapped things up conclusively, such that fans could be justified in scoffing at the idea of a sequel.  I certainly did when Max Payne 3 was announced, and it took a while before I could give it a fair shake.  In the end it's not without problems, and any recommendation should come with a few warnings attached, both for series fans and people just looking for a shooter fix.  Still, credit where it's due, Max Payne 3 earns the right to the title, even if (or perhaps because) it brings a different aesthetic to the table.

On the gameplay front, MP3 mostly succeeds at combining cover-based shooting with the more frenetic, two-fisted gunplay of the first two games. The mechanics and effects of shooting - how bullets hit the environment, how enemies react to being shot, how the guns sound and feel - are quite solid, though I do miss the old unlimited inventory for weapons. Cover works fine, bullet time is largely intact, and (on hard at least) your BT gauge recharges while you're under fire, as opposed to solely through kills. The Last Stand" mechanism gives you a chance to take down your would-be killer after an otherwise fatal injury
date: provided you're carrying painkillers.  Other gameplay modes remove the feature
recommended: but I found it a welcome backstop that didn't cheapen the danger of each encounter.\n\nThere's a good variety of environments for each chapter
hoursPlayed: and even the dingier locations usually don't settle for brown and gray.  A couple flashback chapters touch on Max's life after the second game
voteText: and how he got to Brazil in the first place. An exploration element encourages you to look around
helpfulPercent: as each chapter has various clues that either explain the immediate situation or give broader context: a newspaper with financial reports
votesHelpful: invoices
votesTotal: conspicuous bloodstains
votesFunny: etc. These don't affect the narrative in any way

column31: but a few will die over and over until you figure out what you're doing wrong.\n\nStorywise
column32: I went in with low expectations but was pleasantly surprised at the overall quality. New York Noir has been swapped for a somewhat surreal stranger-in-a-strange-land motif. There's no Norse mythology
column33: but Max remains the fallen hero to end all fallen heroes.  He has since spent his life in a haze of booze and pills
column34: and he's only just waking up to the larger goings-on. The highlighting of key words in a conversation works well with the use of unsubtitled Portuguese

column40: a contrast of South American politics and high society with crushing poverty and pervasive corruption; less shadowy conspiracy and more the kind of evil that might actually happen when no one's looking. The writing does stumble at times

column44: but many of the main characters did make lasting impressions and offered glimpses of deeper personalities. A quiet conversation between Max and his employer was one of the game's high points
column45: where the latter dissects his own flaws with brutal honesty.\n\nMax himself starts off as the alcoholic
column46: anti-heroic killing machine advertised in the trailers

column48: but it's handled plausibly. It quickly becomes obvious that for all his claims of being burned out and washed up
column49: there remains a decent person on the inside: torn between being unable to forgive himself and wanting to be something other than a walking
column51: and still thinking like a cop besides. He's not too jaded to be horrified
column52: and not too busy feeling sorry for himself to fight a grave injustice; a failing
column53: flailing mess of a man that still knows right from wrong.\n\nFew things can top the artistry and efficiency of "I had a dream of my wife. She was dead
column55:
and nothing in Max Payne 3 quite gets to that level. Instead it shoots for something else, confidently building its own atmosphere and narrative, and taking its own chances with the character. Doing my best to discard nostalgia, I don't think it's as well written as the first two games and it was sometimes frustrating to play.  Nonetheless, it's a respectable and respectful followup, a late welcome back for a series I didn't think I wanted to see again.

Like its namesake, Max Payne 3 can be a hazy mess of issues that are more than skin deep.  But also like its namesake, the game succeeds where it counts: killing an army of bad guys in style, all of whom can't seem to grasp that the crazy, wordy substance abuser with the guns stubbornly refuses to die.  Get a good sale price and there's no reason not to pick it up.

Trust us now.  It's time to let me go.

reviewText:
Payne to the Max

The original Payne will always be close to my heart, and the second is right up there in the best sequels of all time list. I was highly suspicious about what Rockstar was doing to my precious Finnish game by making it a trilogy that ends with a bald fat John McClane in the tropical heat of Brazil,  surely they've ruined everything ?

Actually, no they haven't. It's definitely different than the two previous games and I think that's a decidedly good thing (hardcore noire fans calm down there's still segments of good old Jersey which isn't quite New York but it's the perfect place for Max). R* may have left Noir York behind but they're staying true to the originals in gameplay, with a few improvements added. Bullet time remains unchanged and you won't find regenerating health here, pop the pills and struggle on with the incredible new gunplay which is the single biggest plus point for the third game. Max's movements in all directions with any weapon are so fluid that it's hard to appreciate it at times, it just seems so natural that the player will rarely notice it.

For me the story wasn't an important point, but rather served as a great excuse to put the old warhorse out on the battlefield one last time. You get to shoot at the thugs of favelas, senseless paramilitaries and a few mafia goons, armed with a shiny new game engine it's a fun experience that surprised me positively. The story is there at least and it stands on it's own, but only just, if you ask me. No comments on the multiplayer as I haven't played it.

tenouttaten

P.S. Don't make a fourth game R*, quit while you're ahead.

reviewText: Max Payne 3 is a very good Third Person: Shooter. The bullet time mechanic works very well, with solid gameplay. Dolphin dive around areas and go into slow motion and shoot your enemies. You can go into slow motion at any time you want, which enhances the game experience, and you have a certain amount of slow motion, to replenish it you must kill enemies or be shot at. You will heal your self with pain killers that you find throughout areas. The shooting feels fantastic, and is very fast paced, but the gameplay is very repetitive with linear level design, and a low variety of weapons. The story is not as good as the first Max Payne game, but the story still manages to be good, but there is way too many cut scenes and there is a few plot holes in the story that can bug you. The visuals are great, and if the game was to be released today with the same visuals, they would still be impressive. The length of this game is way too short, there are about 3½ hours of cut scenes and 2½ hours of gameplay (6 hours total) that was a huge disappointment and might be the biggest flaw of the game. But the length of the game is not all that bad, there is a fully fledged out multiplayer, and there is quite a bit of replay value in the game, such as finding the rest of the collectables, New York minute were you have a time limit to get through a level and Arcade mode. This can forgive the sad short length of the campaign. The game in my opinion is way too easy, but for a lot of people the game can be very difficult. I never found my self getting stuck on a level, and I only died very few times, but there is a little difficulty spike near the end of the game. If I was to recommend this game, I highly would. The game isn't ''Game Of The Year'' material, but this game is a must buy.

reviewText: Max Paye is back!! Great storytelling combined with classic Max Payne gameplay mechanics (bullet-time, shootdodge) + cover system and no regenerating health (you've got to take painkillers to do tha) make this one a must play experience. The story is dark and gritty and full of violence as expected from Max Payne. Many great setpiece action sequences make this one a true neo-noir experience that rocks the boat hard. A must play for anybody interested in the 3rd person action shooter genre and who likes a good told story that keeps you wanting to see it through to the end!!!

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE
(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Max Payne 3
Original Release: 2012
Genre Tags: Third-Person Shooter; Atmospheric; Story-Rich; Cinematic; Noir; Adult
My Overall Grade: A+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 15-30 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: Auxiliary
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Fans of the intellectual property; Aesthetes; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs

REVIEW
Max Payne 3 is an outstanding action-shooter that offers a strong narrative and a highly cinematic experience. If you are someone who wants raw action, and doesn’t want to see a lot of cutscenes or kill-cams: then you may not enjoy this. However, if you are someone who enjoys games that play like movies, this is something you must play. In my opinion, Max Payne 3 is one of the best cinematographic-action games ever made and likely will be for a long time.

The first aspect I will highlight in defense of my opinion is the writing and dialogue. Max Payne 3 easily has some of the best writing I have ever encountered in a video game. The overall narrative is interesting and entertaining, but the real beauty of the writing shines through in the dialogue. There are several lines throughout the game that will evoke that inner-thought of: “that was a good one.” And the excellent voice acting ices the cake to ensure the cutscenes have an A-one quality that rivals Hollywood movies.

Besides the main cutscenes that give life to the actual narrative, there are also many other cinematic features woven deep into the gameplay mechanics. You can activate Bullet Time® and Shootdodge™ as you play through the fight scenes in each level; doing so will slow time and allow you to perform elaborate kill sequences. Further, bullet-cams and kill-cams will pop up periodically to show some nasty kills. There are also level-specific “special” kills that will slow time and create cinematic opportunities.

The fight scenes encompass the vast majority of the actual gameplay of Max Payne 3. The game is very linear and generally ushers you from one shootout to the next, with a cutscene in between to show more plot development. There are some secret areas and collectibles, but generally the areas where you are in control are rather small and undeviating. However, this is perfectly aligned with the movielike feel of the game; and the levels are well-designed and diverse, so they never feel boring or plain.

The whole experience is brought together nicely by solid graphics and animations, a high level of attention to detail, and advanced physics and particle effects.

Now, Max Payne 3 is the third installment in the franchise. It is technically a direct sequel, although it feels a bit more like a spiritual successor. You can easily enjoy this game without having played the first two. (Of course, it is still best to learn what happened in the story during the previous games). Also the first two installments in the Max Payne franchise were created by different people than this one. This game does go in a bit of a different direction compared to the earlier installments. For example, it isn’t quite as dark and noir; and also eases a bit on the deep, psychological inner-war concept. These, and other differences, upset some fans of the franchise (as seems to be a common theme in new installments of long-standing franchises). So be aware of this. I personally feel that all three games can be appreciated for what they are.

Arcade-mode, timed-mode, higher difficulties, and achievements all contribute to the possibility of many gameplay hours. There is also a multiplayer mode that is pretty fun. During the time I played, there was a decent amount of people who played regularly; although there were times I couldn’t find a game. I actually liked the multiplayer a lot and played it for dozens of hours, but I will admit that most people will probably find it lackluster.

In summary, I highly recommend Max Payne 3 to anyone who would enjoy a heavily cinematic action-shooter and who would appreciate the amazing writing. It is one of the best “plays-like-a-movie” games ever made. Having said that, I can understand some of you just want action. If you want pure gameplay and/or generally skip cutscenes in games, you definitely should look elsewhere for your next shooter.

reviewText:
I love this game. Max Payne 3 is exactly the game a Rockstar-helmed Max Payne game be. Yes, there are cutscenes very frequently, but if you are going to do a cutscene/story heavy game (and MP has always been story heavy), this is the way to do it. Keep your hand on the mouse and keyboard because most of the cutscenes transition immediately back into gameplay.

But nevermind all of that. The Brazilian flavor, the inspired HEALTH soundtrack, and inventive shooting and weapon handling (inventory in particular) combined with incredibly well tuned euphoria-backed animations make this in many ways the finest Max Payne game ever. Yes, it's got a cover system, but in most fights it is a red herring--you will enjoy the game the most and succeed at more fights the more you behave like the Max of old.

And that means when you get to the part where he's at the top of a very long flight of stairs, you know what to do.

reviewText:
Pros:
-Excellent graphics, music and atmosphere
-Great physics engine, you can see the projectile of each bullet fired by the enemy
-Contains an improved version of several game mechanics (e.g. bullet time) from Max Payne 2
-Decent story and gameplay which continues from Max Payne 2
-Has boss fights which kind of involves solving a puzzle
-Lots of achievements, weapons, Easter eggs and collectibles

Cons:
-Too many pointless cut scenes like just a cut scene for opening a door
-Single player mode is very linear
-No more comic-panel style story telling which was found in Max Payne 1 and 2
-Being able to duck/find cover does not match the game mechanics in Max Payne 1 and 2
-Annoying leveling system in Multiplayer
-You have to make an account on Rockstar Social Club to play

reviewText: This is not a game, it's a movie. You literally only play for like 2 minutes and there's a 5 minute cutscene, and this just keeps on going on. Not to mention it's the worst title out of the three Max Payne games. I had more fun playing the first one just last week, and the game is 15 years old. It doesn't look so good but the gameplay holds up really well. Shootdodging and bullet-time is actually possible to use and it was the core of the gameplay. In Max Payne 3 they get rid of all that by severely nerfing the bullet-time to be only used for like 2 seconds tops, and instead added a completely broken and unecessary new core to the game, the cover system. Seriously, the main gameplay you get in that 2 minutes is behind a cover waiting for the AI to push, otherwise if you try and move around have fun dying a few 100 times. The camera movement is really constricting, it completely ruins the freedom of the game, the little it has, and the movement although realistic can f*ck you over a lot of times. The developers knew that this game is insanely hard, so instead of unnerfing the bullet-time so that it would replenish everytime you got a kill even while in slow mo, they add a pain killer every 10 times you die in a sequence. Thanks game for telling me how much I suck. They stuck so much to realism and story they forgot to make a f*cking game.

reviewText:
Great sequel to the Max Payne series!

I remember hearing a lot of complaints about the single player campaign for this game, but I thoroughly enjoyed it. The storytelling is done very well with excellent voice work. Envorionments are detailed and beautiful, especially in the outdoor stages. It helps that the graphics in general look amazing when cranked up to maximum quality. Its no wonder that the game takes up 33gb in harddrive space.

Combat has evolved very well in Max Payne 3. Being able to enter bullet-time and visually see Max run past streaming bullets is quite satisfying. Not as satisfying as watching a closeup slo-mo of a bullet popping the blood bag in an enemie's head. The gore really is top notch here. IT may not be realistic, but it damn sure looks good on screen.

I actually found the combat to be quite challenging. This is the first game where I actually had to turn the difficulty down to the lowest level. I may not be the greatest at shooters, but I did manage to beat the Crysis games on max difficulty.

Anyway, I highly recommend this game, even if you only touch the single player. I only played a few minutes of multiplayer, so I can't really comment on that. It does look like they added much content to the multiplayer since release.

reviewText:
DO NOT BUY THIS IF YOU'RE EXPECTING ANYTHING LIKE THE FIRST MAX PAYNE!
I bought this during the steam sale expecting something similiar to the first ones, the only thing they have in common is the bullet time, the voice actor and the name. Rockstar removed almost everything that was good about the first ones.

DO BUY THIS IF YOU LIKE OVER THE TOP HOLLYWOOD ACTION!

I have only played the single player of this game, therefore I cannot judge the multiplayer aspect.

The gameplay is acceptable in it's core, but boy did they mess up with some aspects.

After every cutscene (which is every second door you go through) you are usually put in a bad position in the middle of the room facing around 7 enemies, equipped with 1 pistol in your hand. Regardless of what you had equipped before said cutscene.
Further ruining this is the weapon switching mechanic. There is no more nice layout showing you all the weapons you collected. You have a stupid circle split into 4 which constantly bugs if you use the scroll wheel (keeps switching between only 2 options) and the default keybindings to said circle are horrible.

There are hidden things in most areas. Newspapers, television clips, clues about the story and parts of golden weapons that you can collect.
Which is a nice feature, I like exploring and finding out more about the story.
But! Max or whoever is on your side is constantly nagging you every 3 seconds to move forward, that you don't have time to look around.
Which pretty much makes you choose between getting more insight into the story while constantly being harassed or rushing through the game because the story tells you to, ruining any immersion.

Every time your life depletes and you still have some painkillers you go into slomo facing the person that shot you giving you a chance to kill him and use a painkiller.
Not a bad idea, if it wasn't ruined by what happens next.
After you kill the guy, you fall on the ground forcing you to get up again.
You can't get into cover instantly from the ground. If you press Q (default key to get into cover) while behind some cover you first stand up and THEN go into cover thus getting shot multiple times again (usually forced into the whole slomo shootoff again on higher difficulties).
Why didn't they bother working out the cover mechanics? They just slapped some half a$$ed attempt into the game.

One thing that I found pretty good was the ability to switch the camera angle so that your character was either left or right of the reticle.
BUT! As expected, there is also a flaw with this.
The bullets hit the target of the reticle regardless of what is between the gun and the reticle.
So most of the time I was hitting an enemy behind a wall even though Max himself was completely behind that wall.

The only reason I kept playing until the end was my hope of there being just a little bit of the old Max Payne in there.
But I found the story to be a boring, cheesy joke. I could not feel anything for the characters at any point in the game, they were all just dull and uninteresting. Everything about it felt forced and mindless.


I actually replayed the first Max Payne about a year ago. I loved every second of it! Everything about that game sucks you in. The way the story is presented, the story itself, the gameplay, the atmosphere, the freedom to save whenever you want.
Even today it's still a refreshing game!


Rockstar couldn't have done much worse with this attempt at Max Payne. They had a solid foundation with the story and gameplay from the first ones. They decided to take Max Payne a completely different route and completely failed to deliver.

If I had to rate it as a Max Payne game I would give it no more than a 3/10. Not even worth buying during a steam sale.

If, however, they made this as an original story I would give it close to a 6/10 probably.
The game has lots of flaws and the story really lacks, but it is an acceptable action game.
I played it on hard difficulty and the challenge was decent.
You can probably have a bit of fun in the multiplayer and it would be worth a couple of bucks if you're looking for an action game to kill some time with.

reviewText:
Oh wow. The story-line. The graphics. The gameplay. Also has a really big multiplayer version, where alot of gamemodes exist.

Long story short, its a badass ♥♥♥♥ing game. Max Payne, a former cop, alcoholist, gets hired by a rich family as a bodyguard, but he's expectations was maybe a bit high about that job...

Max ♥♥♥♥ing Payne. He's almost as badass as Samuel L. Jackson.

9/10

reviewText:
Max Payne 3 is so on rails it's heading straight off a broken bridge at full speed. I haven't played a more quick-time event heavy shooter which feels the need to inconvenience the player at every possible situation. You're constantly stripped of your weapons and put in the worst cover areas imaginable before unskippable cutscenes.

The game quickly becomes incredibly frustrating and expects you to know where every single enemy will come from. It's not fun to shoot 50 bad guys at every single encounter, with ammunition and bullet-time being so scarce it becomes tiresome pretty quickly.

I have no idea what Rockstar was thinking turning Max Payne into some AAA cover shooter, the ending isn't gratifying either. The story elements are predictable forcing every depressing lame line of dialog out of the protagonist every 5 minutes. The game plays and paces like a typical bad Hollywood movie with plenty of explosions to keep the more simple minded players engaged.

I did not have fun and I don't believe many others will either, even fans of the cover shooter genre. I don't have much good to say other than the graphics and animations are excellent along with the voice acting. Max writing is pretty dry and relies on his persistent hard boiled nature too heavily; he just comes across as a depressing low life fool wishing to be killed at every opportunity. Great game 5/10.

reviewText:
A real disgrace for Max Payne series. TBH it is like Rockstar came up with a really bad story and decided use Max Payne series' name to sell it. Max Payne 3 has nothing to do with the series. Characters are just meaningless even Max himself is. This game is just cut scenes + fight against 20 people again and again and again.

Every cut scene makes you change your weapon even drop it automatically sometimes and you always drop your painkillers at beginnings of chapters. It is just ridiculous to have such a system. . Just why?
Most of the time cut scenes end with Max being a complete idiot and covering behind the worst possible places (e.g: http://i.imgur.com/gocpJzd.png During the cut scene Max was at the behind of bar-like-thing at right most side. Then he decides covering behind some luggage might be a better idea and does it).
Most of the time you start chapter with half health since every enemy is covered well but since Max is an inexperienced ex-cop, he just stands there and takes hit.

And... they made such a badass character wear flip-flops. How dare you?? http://i.imgur.com/pbF1UeQ.png

reviewText: As long as you have some tempered expectations this game is brilliant. I can't speak for the multiplayer as I've never touched it but the single player story is everything it should be. Series purists might be put off by how often there are cut scenes and dismayed by the fact that there are numerous fail conditions that can happen that don't involve Max soaking up bullets or explosions. The bottom line is that you get to watch a lengthy summer blockbuster action movie where you play through all the shootouts of which there are many.\n\nMechanically the game is damn near flawless (minus one arbitrary boss" encounter) in that precision and quick thinking are rewarded properly. Making good use of the cover system
recommended: and shoot dodging are essential to beating the game on harder difficulties where even on normal you WILL get flanked by aggressive enemy A.I. that won't let you "stop n' pop" like in other shooters. The guns all have a certain weight to them ( a .50 Desert Eagle just "feels" heavier than a .45 in a very noticeable way) and you'll be forced to mix up your arsenal often. Finishing the game was a satisfying experience and while I didn't feel compelled to return on higher difficulties right after my first pass I came back later with renewed appreciation.\n\nVisually the game holds up really well 2 years after release. Some finer textures and such might not fare well to heavy scrutiny but the environments are varied with tons of background detail and props while the character models respond to gunfire in a sickeningly visceral way. It's pretty hard to take a screen shot that doesn't look good when you are in a shootout. Aurally the voice acting is solid
hoursPlayed: the soundtrack is top notch
voteText: and the various sounds of battle compliment the action well.\n\nOne of the more common gripes I've heard about the game is that the story is lame and it is excruciatingly linear
helpfulPercent: to the point where on a few occasions if you explore the same area for too long when no enemies are around you'll trigger a fail condition because you didn't follow your companion and he's killed in a short cut scene. I can understand that frusturation. What I don't understand is how some would interpret the story as simply dumb and completely senseless without thinking about it. Unfortunately explaining it would be a spoiler but since the story is about Max and is from his perspective that is PRECISELY how it is meant to appear. You are meant to be Max in this situation but you are not meant to influence him. You are meant only to see and feel how he does and not decide who he is. You're meant to get clarity at the same time he does and it does seem dumb as hell when it all falls together
votesHelpful: right? Max thinks so too. There's also a lot of nuanced visual flourishes meant to convey Max's mental issues and state that some might have mistaken for simple grittiness or what have you. Either way the game is considerably smarter than the trailers would have you believe.\n\nIn conclusion I get the impression that the game was a critical success but commercially floundered
votesTotal: considering how quickly it went to sale prices and how frequently the game is 80% off. Maybe I'm just being pretentious in thinking that I "get it" while others looked down on a decidedly less gamey Max Payne. All I know is that as a standalone product the single player game is worth the 20 dollars it goes for now. If you like good action games and can take the time to enjoy a decent narrative then you'd be a complete dunce for passing this up when it's on sale."

reviewText: On my second playthrough I noticed how smart the writing was at times. Social commentary on poverty and structural economic/governmental problems can often be heavy-handed, but here amidst Max Payne's heavy handed violence it seems quite fitting.\nIf you've never seen the Brazilian films Tropa De Elite (Elite Force) 1 & 2, you simply must. They're both excellent and it seems to me that a number of the characters and most of the setting of Max Payne 3 is inspired by or simply lifted from those films.\nMax Payne's story serves primarily to put large numbers of tangos in your line of fire so it does get a little silly but you're playing a game where bullet-time allows you to get sick headshots while floating in mid-air, so all in all I can't complain.

reviewText:
A disappointment and a mess.  If you want to play this, you have to join Rockstar's stupid social club or whatever it is.

Remember when Max Payne was a badass in the first two games... yeah, you won't find that guy here.  I don't even recognize who the guy in this game is supposed to be, because it's not Max Payne, it's gotta be some fake who happens to have the same name.

The most annoying aspect of the game may be the non-stop cutscenes.  Cutscenes happen over and over again every level.  Some cutscenes end with you already being shot at, so you're already taking damage when you gain control.  During every cutscene, the game switches your weapon to the pistol you have in your first slot.  So after every cutscene, you have to switch back to your primary weapon.  Thanks fake Max, I fully intended to engage these 6 enemies with your pistol that holds 8 rounds instead of the 30 round assault rifle you're now holding in your offhand.

The story in this game is incoherent at best, it's like they didn't even bother trying.  You can't have me running around killing hundreds of bad guys, then suddenly have a cutscene where Max decides he's a ♥♥♥♥♥boy who can't handle 6 bad guys and gets captured.  Max is constantly being captured by people who should be putting a bullet in his brain, but don't for no real coherent reason.  Likewise, there are many cutscenes where bad guys could simply shoot him dead, don't, and instead it's just them yelling at each other.  That's right fake Max, go into that room, surrender your gun and beg for the girls life, that will surely work.

I also had plenty of gameplay nitpicks.  If Max gets close to a wall with a gun, he'll point the weapon up in the air.  This is very problamatic since they turned this game into a cover shooter.  Sometimes you'll pop out of cover to shoot and Max will point his weapon up at the ceiling... Thanks fake Max, that's what I wanted to do, shoot the ceiling instead of the bad guys in front of me.

You're also limited in the arsenal you can carry, 2 pistols/smgs and a primary weapon.  If you ever want to dual wield pistols, which is the only real fun in the game, Max has to drop whatever the primary weapon he is carrying.  Eventually, you can't dual wield anymore since you'll run out of ammo in your pistols and no longer have a fallback weapon.  Thanks fake Max, for not allowing me to actually have fun using the dualies.

Shootdodge is very buggy and I stopped using it around 1/4 of the way through the game.  Sometimes I would press it and it would work right away, but other times I'd press it and Max wouldn't know what to do.  Then 3 seconds later it would randomly activate and he'd start diving across the room.  Thanks fake Max, for waiting to dive until I've already been shot up, gotten to cover, and then randomly activating and diving out into the open again.

If you are moving when you try to pick up an item, instead of stopping to pick it up, Max rolls over it and picks it up.  Not the biggest issue, but I was very annoyed when I tried to pick up a gun along the side of the Panama Canal.  Thanks fake Max, when I told you to pick up that gun, I wanted you to roll off the side of the Panama Canal and to your death, how'd you know?

The game has clues and weapon parts scattered throughout.  The clues are pointless, they do nothing and add nothing to the game, I don't know why they're there.  The weapon parts turn your weapons gold if you collect all 3 parts.  Collecting them can be very annoying since the game has spots where you must choose 1 of 2 paths to go.  Behind path number 1 is a weapons part, behind path number 2 is the continuation of the game... Thanks fake Max, for constanly breaking the door/pathway/whatever behind you so I couldn't go check out that other room.

I could go on and on with problems.  This game sucks.  Go away fake Max Payne, bring back the real Max Payne so I can have a fun game with an interesting story.

reviewText:
Even more grizzled...Max Payne returns!

The plot is lifted straight out of Man on Fire...which is ok because I liked Man on Fire.

Bullet time is still just as fun as you remember it and the slow-mo carnage still impresses.

I don't know if I'd call this my favoirte, but I'd certainly describe this as the HARDEST Max Payne game.

Enemies can kill you just as easily as you can waste them.  Mindlessly diving into a room can net you a quick headshot when you run out of ammo and haven't finished off everyone.

Highly recommended for fans of the series.

reviewText:

reviewText:
Max Payne was one of my childhood games (along with Unreal Tournament 2004, Devil May Cry 3, GTA Vice City and TES III Morrowind). Up to now, I still can't forget the cop with monkey face (due to old graphic technology) a.k.a highest NY mobs bodycount mungo with sick humour who only has one thing to do: blast a hole in bad guys' faces in slooooooooooow motion, oh yeah and drug too, that Valkyr drug created nightmares inside Max's mind became one of the first horror segments in video games that I've ever experienced. And then Max Payne 2 came to my life, the awesomeness continued with a love story, Captain Baseball Bat and moar sloooooooooow motion. With me, Max Payne 1 and 2 redefined third-person shooter genre and they remained my favourite games of all time.

When Rockstar Games first announced Max Payne 3, I honestly thought the game would failed because it no longer took place at NY and it didn't have classic noir them anymore. Well, I was wrong...

Let's kick off with the reason why we all play Max Payne for: presentation and story (I won't tell anything related to the story because I want to avoid spoilers). The game is heavily filled with rendered cutscenes instead of comic style cutscene, which will make many Max Payne fans dissappointed. But let me tell you one good thing: these cutscenes are all well-made, I had a great time watching them and I didn't even bother to press skip" at 2nd playthrough. Max continued to narrate in the game and with the I-don't-even-know-how-to-describe-them effects
date: the cutscenes in the game are very unique and cinematic.\nMax Payne is no longer obsessed with his wife and daughter's death

reviewText: Rockstar Games have really achieved a milestone here. The game is perfect: in its captivating story, fluid and responsive game mechanics, picture-like graphics, focus on details, well-done PC optimization and of course the magnificent narration by the one and only James McCaffrey. Even though the game is no longer in the arms of Remedy, Rockstar did an amazing job. The transition between the surroundings: from noirish and snowy/rainy New York to sunny São Paulo is truly impressive. One thing that that's incomprehensible is the infamous double DRM (RGSC & Steam) ((not to mention GTA IV's TRIPLE DRM)), so sometimes one might experience connection problems. I, for one, didn't have problems with activation keys, luckily. I highly recommend you buying this game, for it's easily one of the best things on the gaming market.

reviewText: As a fan of the previous games, I have been very attached to the story of Max Payne and his downfall after losing his family, continuing with life and trying to find meaning to it all. In this game, there is little to nothing about it. The story instead focuses on the resurrection with Max Payne running away from his problems to San Paulo, where as always, trouble seems to find him at every corner. It is safe to say that the story is sub-par at best, but there is still enough there to make some sense and past a certain point in the game, you do stop caring about it all together. It's good that you do stop caring as slow-mo-ing your way around levels shooting people in the face is a significantly better reason to play the game and the story won't destract you from it.\n\nI clocked in more than 30+ hours with no Multiplayer (which by the way is filled with disapointments for me, but I suppose it is playable in the same way the first three Star Wars episodes are watchable) going around each of the levels again and again, diving and creating hell for anyone who stands in my way. The game might seem arcaic by todays standards, but there is simply nothing quite like it. The mechanics and controls of the game are tight enough to allow you to do pretty much anything within reason. I'd recommend the game on those basis alone.

reviewText:
My Personal Score: 3/5PCGaming Wiki Page[pcgamingwiki.com]
Issues: none encountered during playthroughs


Max Payne 3 is currently the best action game that I've ever played and is commendable for staying true to the series' formula while improving its core mechanics. I can imagine Rockstar being tempted to modernize the game in order to broaden its appeal and attract new players but they kept the series' staple gameplay that's almost 15 years old - as of writing - and proved that if it ain't broke, don't fix it. As someone who had several playthroughs of the past two titles, I played Max Payne 3 without even feeling alienated and quickly became accustomed to how the game works; I was still running and gunning my way through waves of thugs as I did so before, feeling like a one-man killing machine out for justice. For those wondering if the difficulty has been toned down compared to the previous titles: it hasn't and you will die a lot in this game, even if you're a series veteran because the AI is programmed to be very aggressive and will always try to flank Max in every opportunity possible. Overall an excellent action game that will appeal to old fans and new players craving for a chaotic and hardcore experience.

I couldn't hold the same regard for the story though. Even with its high production values, Rockstar's attention to detail, and amazing performances from the cast, the story couldn't win me over and I can't sway the thought that this game shouldn't have been made in the first place. The previous game already established that Max finally achieves peace and accepts that his wife and daughter are dead forever; he realizes that no amount of revenge could ease the pain and he vows to live with that until he dies. Fast forward 9 years later and Max is shown with his life down on the rocks and has an addiction to alcohol and painkillers. He develops a negative attitude to everything surrounding him and he denounces the American dream which he once had. I seriously couldn't get why the new writers presented Max that way since 9 years is more than enough to change a person's life. I felt that Dan Houser and the other writers were going for the Max Payne 2 route where the point of that game existing in the first place is to show that Max doesn't learn from his mistakes but it doesn't work if you do it a second time after your main character already sworn that he already got his redemption. The writers tried to make connections with the past titles, putting small references here and there to appease the old fans but I think it would've been better if they went the reboot/remake route and showed us what vision of Max they had in their head because they're just feeding off the scraps that Remedy sold them.

The story's not bad, mind you. Sure, there are glaring plot holes and it doesn't really explain well why certain events happened the way they happened but it's a passable story for the kind of ambitious game that they were making. It's just that for someone who replayed the Remedy-made games a lot of times, Max Payne 3 has been kind of a let down in the story department. It was a good attempt on Rockstar's part but old-timers may not have the same satisfying experience as they had in Noir York City.



I had a dream of my wife.
She was dead.
But it was all right."



And there you have it."

reviewText:
I've never quite worked out what to make of Max Payne 3. It's a really curious game. Almost like, I dunno, it's showing off how good R* are at world building first and then there's some Max Payne stuff chucked in there later around that.

The thing is, when it works, it's absolutely riveting and tremendous. Both the game and the story get off to a really slow and shaky start. You spend more time watching Max Payne 3 than you do playing it for way, way too long. Short firefights punctuated by lots of story punctuated by short firefights punctuated by lots of story. It can be really, really frustrating too. But at some point, it kinda settles into a happier (OK, happy is not a word I should really use when it comes to Max Payne) groove.

Then there's the favela which is an incredibly showy-off walking simulator wedged in the middle of an AAA game about shooting people in the head in slow motion whilst muttering about your pills. It's a glimpse into a universe where AAA doesn't rely on shooting people in the face but it's also, again, a guided tour of R*'s DVD collection the way it's pieced together. And that's sort of OK, I guess because it wouldn't -be- R* without that.

And after that, it starts letting you play the game proper. The balance between cut scene and videogame sorts itself out and the little frustrating bits of shooting it let you do before finally transition into longer firefights where it feels absolutely properly tense and urgent.

There's a few missed beats in the story. Sometimes things are a bit too grim and dark and slip into violence for violence's sake to shock you through the face and show you how nasty the people you're up against are but y'know, videogames and the tone is all over the shop. Like someone truly believes it's a sort of Tarantino does film noir but no-one told them that most of the time, Tarantino isn't realllly something to aspire to unless you've got a thing for feet and celebrity.

But then it all comes together in the airport and I'm on the edge of my seat, running through this level, glass shattering everywhere, bullets flying left and right and the game gets the bullet ballet bang on. There's a ACTION BLOCKBUSTER ending to it too and then you're left with that sort of wow, that was actually fantastic sensation for a while until it sinks in that for about 7 hours of the game, you were mainly watching a guided tour of someone's DVD collection and... why couldn't I play more? Why couldn't I step a bit to the left without the game killing me off? But OK, those shader effects are incredible so maybe I can forgive it?

Weird game. I'd absolutely recommend playing it through because if nothing else, only Left4Dead has more muttering about pills in it.

reviewText: If you are a fan of the Max Payne franchise, do not but this game.  Everything about it just feels off, from the combat to the story.  Rockstar chose to drop the old comic book and noir story telling in favour of a more cinematic approach, and in doing so took away much of the charm that made Max Payne what it was.  On the topic of combat, the game tries to automate many features (like painkillers and save points) rather than letting that player regulate these things by themselves (yes there is a mode which does not auto-utilise painkillers, but it should not require that the combat be at an incredibly difficult level as well).  Furthermore, the level design emphasises a basic cover-bases system (insert generic 3rd person shooter here) rather than fully utilising the bullet-time elements the series has become famous for.  Overall, as a fan of the series, I was quite disappointed with this entry but have hopes that a good developer like Rockstar can raise the bar for the next instalment.\n\nOn an unrelated note, I did experience a number of technical bugs in my play through with an Nvidia 500 series card.

Me: Take this rifle and go Max.
Max: Hold on I'm going to narrate for a bit.
Me: Same old Max.  Wait, why did you put down the rifle.
Max: I have a pistol, I'm going to use this.
Me: No use the rifle, there are guys sniping in the next room.
Max: Wait, lets cue a cutscene as I saunter into the room...
Me: No!
Max: and I'll walk right into the middle of the room so they see me...
Me: No no no!
Max: and I'll drop my rife for this uzi.
Me: NOOO.  Crap get to cover.
Max: Nah, how about bullet time.  Here I'll aim for you, you shoot this guy, but only him, I'm serious.
Me: Why!  Let me move the mouse, that guy over there is sniping...
Max: That's stupid shoot this guy or I won't let you do anything.
Me: Fine.
Max: Now I will hide behind cover and snipe with an uzi.
Me: Wait what?  Why are you still exposed with this cover system.  Let's move back.  What? I can shoot through walls and around obstacles if I avoid the cover system.  And I can snipe from a block away with an Uzi.  What is going on.
Max: That's not important, whats important is I'm taking control of walking for a bit, and cutscene, ok heres a pistol, I've alerted the enemy, bullet time, go.  Shoot those three guys now!
Me: Screw you Max, you know your in a game right?
Max: Nooo.  We don't do that anymore, or jump, or require bullet time for bullet dodge, have parallel symbolic subplots, dreamsequences, carry more than a couple weapons, have physical bullets outside of bulletime, dutch angles, have a femme fatal, thrown projectiles, melee in SP, effective NPC allies, or puzzles.  Screw thinking, I'll do that for you.

reviewText: On its face, this game is quite similar to Max Payne 1 and 2, enough that I'd be confident recommending it to anyone who enjoyed the first two games. Now, there are a number of major differences. This is a modern shooter and so a large change is made- the addition of a cover system. You end up using a mix of cover and bullet time to defeat a large number of enemies, and I felt that enemy damage was cranked up a lot to compensate for the addition of cover. That said there is just not as much gameplay in this as there was in the first two, as instead of the in-game narration style of the first, MP3 is broken up frequently by long cutscenes, to which you are fed story. The story itself is standard revenge fare and most times it feels like it's being fed to you rather than you guiding it along in any meaningful way, though this is a corridor shooter at best. I felt that the characterization of Max was spot on and the tone of the dialogue was true, though not sure if I felt that the character fit the South American-styled story, and the justification for Max's inclusion in it was shaky at best. That said a thoroughly enjoyable, though short game, with less actual gameplay than even Max Payne 2's short running length.

reviewText:
Rockstar proves to be a worthy successor of Remedy and returns with Max Payne 3 for an exceptional experience in the saga which we all love. Leaving New York, Max moves to Sao Paolo to start a new life, but he quickly gets into a huge trouble and needs to do things in the Max way.

The story and the narration (specially the voiceover) are exceptional and really fun to listen. The script is clever and Max has some really good lines. It’s almost like reading a very good book, except the shooting of many-many bad guys. This might be a problem for some FPS lovers who do not like the frequent interruption of long narrations between action sequences, but for me it worked great.

Beside that the action itself is greatly polished and smooth. Bullet time works just as in Max Payne 1 and it is very fun to use, and necessary to use to remain alive. There are many type of weapons, guns which most of them you can dual-wield and there is also a neat cover system to enhance the action. Grenades can be only used in Multiplayer, and there are NO additional tools or gear you could use (like bulletproof vest or knifes for melee).

The game is beautiful and highly detailed with care which is Rockstar’s strength. The map design is amazing with the detailed interiors, makes the world really alive and immersive.

There is also multiplayer with deathmatch and some survivor co-op missions (which are fun) but we all know that this game is played for the single player experience. And in that part, this game did incredibly well.  More co-op missions with story elements could be good though.

This game is a true gem in the TPS library of games and an exceptional story which everyone needs to see and play. I have replayed it for the 2nd time just to be part of the story again. May Payne is the man.

9/10 Excellent

reviewText:
Max Payne 3 isn't looking to reinvent the wheel and it's safe to say it hasn’t changed much from previous games in the series. It’s still a short, linear, straight action-packed third-person shooter. Each of the 14 chapters begin with a cool cinematic, after which you start at point A, clear rooms after rooms of enemies, essentially just shooting your way to point B, enjoy another cutscene, repeat. But with that said, was it fun? Well, that depends.

Story-wise, I can't say the plot is too elaborate. It has a very predictable twist and the ending is somewhat disappointing. However, the originality of the story lies in the presentation. The cutscenes are fun to watch, the voice acting is top notch, and the writing is clever. For fans of hard-boiled and noir detective fiction, the way the protagonist narrates the story is a real treat. It may come across as cheesy sometimes, but I just loved every line of it and felt it did a perfect job giving you a glimpse into the psyche of Max. Fans of the series will feel right at home with the narrative. It also helps that the amazing graphics and sound go a long way toward giving the game a realistic feel.

My first complete playthrough took me approximately 8-10 hours, and I enjoyed every minute of it, but whether or not it's fun enough to justify a buy will be based on your tolerance for linear and somewhat simple gameplay. The shooting and slow motion mechanics can be very fun once you get them down but don't expect the game to reward you with ability or weapon unlocks that can open up new strategies--combat stays the same from beginning to end. Seeing as the game is relatively short however, it shouldn't get repetitive enough to make the first playthrough feel like a grind. The story is engaging and does a good job adding more layers to Max's persona, whom despite his flaws, is truly a great protagonist and a hero that you love to cheer for.

reviewText: [wrote this since it's dirt cheap again] My favorite grimaced alcoholic detective returns with nice improvements on the previous 2 games. The tough difficulty is back with more bite, as Max will die from headshots in single-player instantly and enemies are more plentiful and aggressive, making the new cover system a need when you're out of bullettime. The aiming in the game is tight, meaning you will score headshots in bullettime if you've aimed well and fired single shots at a time, something that was absent from the first two games with most weapons, and there may be some difficulty keeping track of the small dot reticule because of this change. There are proper physics in MP3 and the impact of bullets can be felt well, either stumbling an enemy or the player, dependent on the bullet caliber & muzzle energy. Multiplayer is finally in the series and is frustrating from all the seasoned players at first, but rewarding when you get a good feel for the game and have unlocked a few items, given how tight the controls/aiming is. I'd recommend beating the single-player at least once before heading online, though there doesn't seem to be many players around these days.\nThe game is definitely weak story-wise, and MP3 moves away from the alleyways, warehouses, and abandoned buildings of New Jersey to Rio de Janeiro. MP3 also ditches a lot of the campiness in the first 2 games for more cool & gritty. There are also some glitches but they're avoidable for the most part and aren't too common in my experience. The levels were done with a good amount of detail in mind, even if it's just a flashy nightclub you blaze through in a few minutes, some cramped favelas, or a large party yacht, and are all rendered beautifully, somewhat justifying the 32 gigs of so of HDD space this game takes up. HEALTH, the noise band, did a great job on the score as well, and provides a somber mood but with electronic intensity.\nOverall, it's a polished and tight third person shooter for those twitchy, arcadey gamers that just want to feel like a single-man army in a modern action movie, dodging bullets and shooting akimbo while diving through the air, with a hefty amount of challenge to make it feel like more of an accomplishment to beat

reviewText:
I beat this twice on the Xbox 360, and when I saw a great deal come up on the PC version, I couldn't pass it up, and neither should you. It's usually on sale, but well worth the asking price.

If you are a fan of Se7en, Dirty Harry, Sunset Boulevard, Pulp Fiction, The Big Sleep, Blade Runner, Drive, Taxi Driver, or Miami Vice, then this game will be right up your alley.

Max Payne 3 is the gritty, dark, and depressing tale of a former NYPD cop named Max Payne, who is battling his demons: alcoholism, his mental stability, and the murder of his family. He now resides in Brasil working as a security officer for the wealthy Brancos, a family with some secrets they want to kick under the rug.

The plot very much plays out like a well-made film and serves as a big nod to its inspirations. The story has so many ups and downs-- it's a wild ride! Max's narration is as well-done as it is cynical and unreliable, which is typical to film noir. Cutscenes are very cinematic, with multiple angles, important words popping up on the screen, and some sweet post-processing effects.

Graphics are awesome. The levels are incredibly detailed, lighting effects are magnificent, etc. For a four year old game, it certainly doesn't look the part, and puts my $3k rig to shame.

Sound design is very well done, from the soundtrack to the effects.

Haven't touched multiplayer but there's not a lot of people on it anymore sadly.

Well worth the $20 but definitely worth the sale price!

9/10
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Unpopular opinion, I know. But Max Payne 3 overall is easily my favorite of the series.
The story, voice acting, dialogue and setting are all fantastic. This game is criminally underrated.
The gameplay is everything I could of wanted out of a Max Payne game, and I honestly can't think of anyway it could of been done better.
It's a shame that this was the last game ever to come out of Rockstar North. But I can't imagine a better swan song to a studio so great.
Even if you've never gotten into the series before,  please get this game. You will not be dissapointed.
Can't really speak to the quality of the multiplayer because it seems to be all but dead at this point. (You can still find a match at certain times of the day) Though I do remember it being fairly enjoyable when I played back when the game innitially released.
20$ for the campaign alone is a very fair price.

Gotta give it a 10/10

reviewText:
This is just about a perfectly executed third-person shooter – it’s got great gunplay, tons of weapons, satisfying explosions, and excellent set pieces which will get torn to shreds by the hundreds of  bullets flying every which way.

You’ll have to utilize your ability to slow down time to compete with the dozens of enemies the game throws at you (literally – there are some areas where you’re plowing through entire platoons of mooks.) By the end of the story mode, Max will have a kill count in the high hundreds – yet it still never feels like it gets old blowing a gaping hole in someone’s skull.

The enemies aren’t pushovers, either – they’ll (mostly) intelligently make use of cover, flanking attacks, and covering fire to try to defeat you. Some of the more difficult ones also pack grenades, keeping you from turtling in a corner.

The game is difficult, yet fair – difficult in that even on normal mode (which is what I played through the story on) you can expect to run into fights that will kill you – and will manage to kill you again even when you know (more or less – there’s enough noise in the AI routines that enemies won’t always move the same way between attempts) what’s going to happen. Thankfully, the game will take pity on you – the first couple times you die, you’re transported back to the last checkpoint (the game’s pretty good about saving pretty often) fully healed. If you manage to die some more, it’ll start you off with some painkillers (the game’s medkit-equivalent) as well.

The story’s not too much to talk about – it’s Max Payne being all Max-Payne-y, will all the noir ham-handedness that implies. It’s basically just a vehicle to get Max in front of small armies of mooks in various locales.

Less of a negative, and more of a rant – Max; I know you’re apparently all about the form-over-function, but neither a suit and tie nor a loud Hawaiian t-shirt are rated to protect you from bullets. Many of the thugs you’re going up against know that, and they wear _bulletproof vests_. Feel free to take one from somebody that you headshotted. Especially after you basically declare war singlehandedly against South America, it’s just downright stupid that you’re not protecting your vitals with anything heavier than a good starch.

Anyway, great game that I finally got around to playing (I bought it during the X-mas sale of 2013!) It runs beautifully on high settings, even though my computer has been in dire need of an upgrade for a while now.

reviewText: Max Payne 3 can be summarized in one sentence: Shooting Brazilian gang members and paramilitary forces with the use of slow motion and John Woo's Hard Boiled in one hell of a game. I used to play the previous two Max Payne games back in my original Xbox and the third game is hard to describe. The genre of the game is a hybrid of crime thriller with a sheer blend of intense firefights, containing the cinematography of Tony Scott's 2004 film, Man on Fire. Strangely enough, Max Payne is more cynical about himself and his surroundings. If you know what happened in the first two games, then you should know why he acted in such attitude. The story in the game is rather...complex up to the point that it is confusing on what's happening and who's who. The narration mixes up to Max's current situation in Brazil and his past in New Jersey and Panama Canal. Unfortunately, the story progression tends to go back and forth of Max's past and present, ruining the mood on certain points of the story. Without a doubt, the gameplay is highly impressive with excellent body movement and human flexibility for Max to fire his weapon at any position. However, the game does feel a bit repetitive and can be difficult for some gamers to not play the entire game in one sitting. Overall, the game is recommended to those who like slow motion, action movies particularly John Woo's Heroic Bloodshed films, and gun play. However, the game may not be for some gamers who are more story centric (even though there were some surprising moments in the story). The story's good and may feel a bit uncomfortable" in certain parts of the story. It has my recommendation."

reviewText:
The game is great. Awesome graphics, music, multiplayer and ofc the story. Also, it has epic quotes:

Fate was mocking me, the same bad joke I'd heard a hundred times before.
The setting had changed, but the rest was all too familiar.
I couldn't remember the last time I'd felt anything but regret.
All those failures I'd banked had been gathering interest.
It had been so long since I'd seen a good idea, I'd forgotten what they looked like.
This was the longest suicide attempt in history.
In their faces I saw myself, the ghost of my mistakes.
No amount of pills could numb this much pain.
Every gunshot echoed in the past.
I'd filled my body with so much poison it was all I could taste.
People kept telling me I was going to hell. Seemed I'd arrived early.
Guilt had ambushed me once again. I never saw her coming.
It felt like I was running blind, chasing the skyline.
My world was fading around me, turning everything to black.
I just wanted to be back at Marty's, staring into the bottom of a glass.
I wasn't the man I used to be, and even he wasn't up to much.
Here I was again, waging a war that wasn't mine for reasons I didn't fully understand.
Once again I'd confused remorse with purpose.
Things had a way of turning out right for all the wrong people.
All I was doing was making a bad situation worse.
I was a problem trying to be a solution.
I was trying to put on an act when the curtain was already down.
All I had left was emptiness, and that had rarely served me well.
There was no saving anyone, least of all me.
I was back on the same path, and I knew where it led.
I was so far behind the pace, I was running a different race.
Reality was about to come crashing down.
This was my sentence. To keep making same mistakes.
It felt like every step was taking me further away from the truth.
My old friend Futility was back, whispering sweet nothings in my ear.

9/10

reviewText:
The best part of Max Payne 3 is that Houser and co decided to make a pulp, self-contained game instead of making it the third part of the Max Payne story. Like a nth volume in the airport novel dadfiction series.

Worth playing just for soundtrack and great level of detail, not bad as a whack-a-mole shootman.

The only significant downside is that Bullet Time is intended to be used more than it should be - you have to abuse it at every opportunity if you want to survive against a horde of hitscan enemies even on Normal difficulty.

reviewText:
This movie is way too long.

I did like that it let you briefly play a video game between scenes. I think I would have enjoyed it more if it let you play for more than three minutes at a time, because I couldn't really get into the flow of playing the game. Also once I ragequit during a QTE combat sequence that seemed way harder than any of the shooting parts.

Every scene in the movie has near-constant voice-over by the actor playing Max Payne and always ends with Max Payne letting himself get surrounded by guys shooting at him, and he always switches to the pistol -- even if it is out of ammo. You will probably run out of ammo repeatedly. Max Payne 3 does the Uncharted thing where almost every bad guy has a different weapon, but somehow has only 5-10 bullets left when you kill him, and that's the only source of ammunition. I don't know about you, but I get tired of having to having to discard my gun and go pick up another during a shootout.

I did like Max Payne 3 enough to finish, but there are so many great shooters on PC (for instance Wolfenstein: The New Order, not to mention the first two Max Payne games) that I can only give a slight recommendation.

Edited: changed to recommend, because the game is still pretty badass, even though there's not much gameplay in the single-player campaign.

reviewText: Max Payne 3 is an extremely linear third person shooter with levels comprised of a single path. In fact, the non-chronological storyline is the only nonlinear aspect about this game. While this streamlined approach deprives the player the freedom of gameplay choices in Rockstar's more renowned open world titles like Grand Theft Auto V and Red Dead Redemption, it gives the game a much more tightly crafted narrative and greater level of direction in its scripted set pieces. Shootouts play out in an extremely fluid fashion, the camera framing action sequences with great care and the bullet-time" mechanism slowing down time to capture the journey of a bullet fired from Payne's gun all the way to its intended target
date: whose blood splatter and falling corpse have an almost majestic quality.\n\nThe linear gameplay does get repetitive even for fans of shooters
recommended: but the trade-off is the high level of control the developers had in crafting every minute detail. The locales are so intricately rendered that they almost feel like on-location movie shoots; from poverty-stricken Brazilian favelas & dilapidated buildings to glitzy dance clubs & high-end party yachts
hoursPlayed: each location has a sensory quality so strong that you can practically smell the air. Max Payne himself is also a fantastic environmental fixture
voteText: his appearance changing as dramatically as the scenery. In stark contrast to the typical musclebound videogame protagonist who overcomes obstacles and inexorably saves the day
helpfulPercent: Max is a tragic figure who fails almost every task put before him. I have not played the previous games in the series
votesHelpful: but with Max Payne 3 being set after the death of his wife & child and retirement from the police force
votesTotal: the pathos of his character arc strongly echoes in his voice-over narratives (usually during hyper-stylized & visually striking comic book-esque cutscenes). The voice actor does an outstanding job of capturing just how burned out and broken this man is
votesFunny: making for an all-around compelling character.\n\nIt's difficult to universally recommend this game to those new to the series because of how hit or miss it is; your enjoyment of it is almost entirely contingent on how compelling you find the narrative and player character. While some may find it tedious

column16: Brazil and told through the eyes of an anti-hero unlike any other in videogaming. His voice-overs alone are enough to keep many players grinding through a lot of similar

reviewText: I've been a May Payne fan ever since the first one came out so I was worried about the new direction Rockstar was taking about 'the new Max'. After completing the campaign I have to admit that it isn't bad at all. The presentation is great, Max's voice actor delivers and the whole atmosphere, though not New York, comes together. The graphics are great, the physics are nice and I didn't have any problem with the music or sounds. BUT and it is a big but: there are couple of things which simply killed the game for me. First. if either MSAA or FXAA is enabled, it screws up mouse movement BIG time. Seems like Rockstar still can't properly develop for the PC. Second: the enemies are so bullet-spongie that you can only advance with headshots which is not what I've wanted and also makes certain situations a nightmare. Third: usually I don't have a problem if games take over my character to advance to the next area/level but here it's just ridiculous. Also it constantly switches back to the default weapon which sometimes can screw you over. Fourth: weird gameplay issues like iniating a reload, enter bullet time then exiting the cover simply cancels the reload... WHAT?? Also other weird movement issues... So yeah, great ideas ruined by technical and gameplay problems. As for the multiplayer side of things: it would be a nice touch, however it's still full of cheaters... worthless. To be honest I partially regret my purchase since I didn't wait till the price was low enough. I wanted to write that ' I would only recommend this game if you want a nice singleplayer experience for couple of hours and you can get the game for 5€ or less', however after thinking it through: NO, don't get this game, watch the story on YouTube and get another one instead.

reviewText:
This game... It feels like something that came back haunting me from the past. I remembered when I played the first two Max Payne games; scarring my childhood for good and turning me into an adult. Like a bird when it throws its chick from the nest; you either learn to adapt or fall down and die. Just like this game.

As much as linear as it is,  it provides me with excellent gameplay, like an old Scotch to drown my bitterness into revenge for all the respawns and death scenes I had throughout the game.
The story, characters and soundtrack in general is something to admire, considering everyone's (at the time) doubts that the PC version will be nothing more than another ♥♥♥♥ stain of a PC port.

To conclude my review and stop babbling;
I love every moment of it. From start to finish. Like Max loved his wife.

*sips a drink of Scotch in Max's honor*

reviewText: When it comes to story-telling, Rockstar pulled it off perfectly with the Max Payne series. MP3 could probably be one of the true single-player games that deserve a place in the books of gaming history. Well-paced story, brilliant gameplay, and a satisfying end to the franchise.\nAlthough, it was a beautiful game, it had its downsides. Surely, I can't say it's better than Max Payne 2, because sadly, it's not. The characters weren't fully fleshed out, the multiplayer was a huge letdown, and it wasn't too engaging. But, considering it's Rockstar, I have total faith that if they made another game in the series (Most probably, no), they wouldn't overlook the cons of MP3.

reviewText:
The story is good, and the gameplay is good, but together they don't make all that much sense.
You'll end up wanting more, especially when you figure out that you can't skip cutscenes effectively in the arcade mode.
The multiplayer is third person Call of Duty deathmatch with slow motion, and all in all it's not a bad game if you get it on sale.
If you go in expecting that wonderful mix of noire and Jonh Woo action from the past games, you will be sorely dissapointed, but if you expect a good modern shooter on sale, you'll be thouroughly surprised by the sheer amount of polish on this odd gem.

reviewText:
I've been a huge fan of Max Payne games thus far - I've completed Max Payne 2 more times than I care to count - I consider it up there with classic games like Ocarina of Time.

I've really tried to like this one - I've finished it twice (I think, have restarted it a few times over the months also), and just opened it up again.

Max Payne 3 is an interesting movie I guess (better than that horrible hollywood adaptation), but it's not much of a computer game.

Max stands off-centre, so gameplay is highly unintuitive - I have no idea what I'm shooting at half the time.  Objects obscure your view that don't obscure Max's line of sight or gunfire.  There are more gameplay gripes, but that's the biggest.

It's technically possible to get good" at this game

reviewText:
So, at first I wanted to play it whilst I had no internet connection for a while.

Nope, couldn't do it, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Rockstar DRM whilst playing via Steam didn't accept it.

So, meh, onwards we go with a solid internet connection, I log in to Rockstar Social Club, activate my game and crash.
Okay, crashes happen, lets reboot the game and see what happens, now, I press my ENTER key as hard as I can, but to no avail; it seems incredibly delayed and just didn't function properly. My game wouldn't get past the menu screen for a few seconds, and yet again it crashes.

Now, at this stage, I'm pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off, so I go for it a third time before deciding this game is ultimately unplayable.
And my god, I can pass the menu screen. After waiting a few seconds because it is for some reason delayed(?), I manage to configure my options before crashing again.

So no, I wouldn't recommend this game.

* Based off of 10 minutes of trying to get the game started.

reviewText:
Even though it's not as good as Max Payne and Max Payne 2: the Fall of Max Payne, Max Payne 3 still manages to be a thrilling experience with a dark and gritty story and incredibly solid third person shooter mechanics that offers immense satisfaction while playing.

The Good:
· Bullet Time Is Back: after being gone for many many years, the coat-wearing, pills-nibbling ex-cop is back. The gameplay feels authentic to the original while delivering something entirely fresh to the current standard third person shooter formula; Bullet Time. The player can slow down time to land more precise shots, or dive through the air in an iconic actionmovie-esque way while you can feel the bullets missing you by just a hair...
· Incredibly Detail: ... and every single one of those bullets is individually rendered into the game. The AI will react to where you shoot them, Max Payne himself can 360° around himself even while laying down on the ground and the game cuts from cutscene to gameplay flawlessly. Overall Max Payne 3 has an uncanny amount of detail to it, from the textures to the precision and the the movement among many others.
· A Surprisingly Large Amount Of Replayability: after the lengthy story is completed and all of the campaign collectibles are collected you can get into the multiplayer or the New York Minute mode that gives you a minute to complete a level and rewards you with bonus time for every enemy you kill... without any chechpoints along the way.
· Superb Voice Acting: Max's original voice actor is back and every other personage in the game is beautifully voiced. Their tones and accents fit the situations and the character's movements, making for incredible voice acting that I've rarely seen done this good before.

The Bad:
· The Story Doesn't Live Up To The Previous Games: previous games had plenty of memorable characters (Mona Sex and Vinni Gognitti among others) but the characters in Max Payne 3 feel flat and uninterresting. The story had me in its grip long enough, but in the end I cared too little for anyone else besides Max. The overall quality of the story in dumbed down by these uninterresting characters, which is unfortunate but not too troublesome.

The Ugly:
· Max Payne 3 is downright gorgeous. Rockstar is generally known for their open-world games with amazing visuals, but with the linear Max Payne 3 they put a lot of extra effort into the visuals and detail. From the lightning to the materials and the uncanny amount of detail, this game is one of the prettiest of its year.

Final Verdict:
· Compared to most third person shooters, Max Payne 3 stands out due to its authenticity and fresh mechanics for the genre with tons of content that will keep you coming back long after the first time. 8/10

reviewText:
The noir shooting saga continues as Max Payne who lost his family years ago now heads to Brazil to try to escape his past and demons. Max however finds himself yet again in the middle of a bloody affair where he can only trust his Beretta 92FS... Oh wait apparently its a M1911 now, and his addiction to painkillers.

This game is one of the better third person shooters in a long time, the gunplay is precise, the guns sound and feel like they have weight and power, and with the Euphoria Engine the impact of every bullet is mirrored in the brazilians you shoot.

The one complaint I have is that you can't skip all cutscenes and sometimes they do mess up the phasing of the game, however, the cutscenes and dialouge is once again masterfully done with James McCafferey voicing an older more disgruntled Max.

The music is also absolutley fantastic and Health deliver perfect tunes for gunning down hordes of guidos and brazilians. And when the action gets lower and the noir kicks in, Rockstar still kept that iconic piano tune from the previous games to set up dark and depressing scenarios.

To end this review I strongly recommend the game for new players wanting to try a solid fun shooter, and also for all of the veterans wanting another brilliant entry in Max's story.

8/10

Two points from Gryffindor for unskippable cutscenes where the game isn't actually loading. I'd give them back when R* eventually fixes this misunderstanding (If you want to replay the game for another couple of times it becomes unbearably annoying). Other than that the game absolutely rocks.

They managed to reincarnate the good old Max Payne (I don't mean the second game which I actually can't stand) into another masterpiece without destroying the badass atmosphere.

It's kinda sad though I can't play the whole game without being hit at all (scripted wounds don't count:) as me and a friend of mine used to pull off in the original Max Payne.

reviewText:
This is a fantastic game, if you like cutscenes and thats about it.

However if you do have standards, and you don't like cutscenes with headache inducing effects about a really depressed ♥♥♥♥ then sorry this game isn't for you. If you enjoy actually playing the game and getting into it quick well screw you most of the entire first part of the game is cutscenes(this is not hyperbole in any way shape or form). My favorite cutscene was the one at the start of the game, and by that I mean the one before the start of the game where it forced me to watch Max be depressed for five minutes.

But that wasn't the bad part, no no no, the bad part was that I had the audacity to alt tab during that first cutscene to shut off my music(I was expecting the game to start approximately 30 minutes faster than it actually did) and the game went into a crappy windowed mode that cut off part of the screen. Keep in mind that this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ unskippable cutscene was before I had acess to an options menu or anything.

THEN I get into the game and find out its a cover based shooter, so I think to myself Yeah I can work with this" and then I discover the bug where Max will jam his arm into the wall and shoots uselessly into the air. He doesn't even have the decency to shoot into the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ wall. So I'm like whatever I can deal with half an hour of cutscenes where Max is all depressed at me
date: I can deal with bugs that make the cover based shooting useless in a cover based shooter.\n\nThe straw that broke the camel's back though was the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ weapon switch system. Now you see the weapon switch system is really important in a shooting game
recommended: and its something games as far back as ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ DOOM GOT RIGHT. But not here NO NO NO
hoursPlayed: you don't actually get to see which weapons you're going to switch to you just switch to them. You're probably all like "Well so what that seems like a fairly petty complaint" Well you see Max never learned what a shoulder strap was so you can't dual wield pistols AND carry a primary weapon at the same time. So if you press the "dual wield button" by mistake in a hectic action scene meaning to switch to your shotgun you could just accidentally drop your shotgun automatically and instantly.\n\nBest part about it the gun switch UI can't be held down and dissapears in a fraction of a second. So I can't even take inventory of my weapons. Other games like Half Life had a little GUI at the top/bottom of the screen that showed you the weapon options for that slot. Other games like Doom/Half Life/Quake/EVEN ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ REDNECK RAMPAGE had a better weapon switching mechanic than this and for a game of this production value
